PETITION.TITLE: Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROBERTSON; WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Walsh, I present the following petition from 33 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public respect for the Government and the institution of Parliament is diminished by the non-disclosure of pecuniary interests of Ministers of the Government.

That on August 2nd 1979, the Minister for Communications announced through the Parliamentary Press Gallery that he had agreed to repay in 3 instalments of $100 ,000 at 10 per cent interest the sum of $300,000 which had been misappropriated.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Retail Trading Hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MISSEN; MARTYR

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Martyr, I present the following petition from 251 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
2. That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory, the present restrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia may be lifted.

3. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
4. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
5. The deregulation of trading hours would force small retail companies out of business.
6. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.

Your Petitioners most humbly Pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Ensure that retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory continue to be regulated by Ordinance as happened in the past.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans: Ex-servicewomen
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as '' Australian Soldiers'' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: That:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage list.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region, in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 , as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: If half of the wage increase anticipated in the Budget Papers for 1982-83 is in fact granted before a general wages freeze is implemented, would not pay-as-you earn tax receipts be reduced by about $600m and the Budget deficit, net of Commonwealth wage savings, therefore increase by about $500m? Does the Government regard another major expansion of the Budget deficit as irresponsible? If so, what action will be taken to reduce this possibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question, of course, is a hypothetical one. If both the State governments and Federal Government were to apply immediately the $700m that is available after a wage freeze to the re-employment of the people, those people, of course, will pay taxes and there will not be such a decline in pay-as -you-earn receipts at all. As I would not have any precise figures I will refer this matter to the Treasurer who is the responsible Minister. But it seems to me that, assuming that the money is used for job creation purposes, it will, of course, generate more taxation payments.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that indirect taxes in New South Wales have increased during Labor's six years of office by nearly 40 per cent more than the consumer price index for the same time? Is it further a fact that New South Wales is one of the most indirectly taxed States where each person is paying indirect taxes of $577 while in other States indirect taxes range from $409 to $440 per person? Can the Minister inform the Senate what effect these high indirect taxes have on the economy of New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that New South Wales, in the past Budget and in the mini Budget before it, has had a direct raid upon the people of an enormous range of indirect taxes and charges and New South Wales now is suffering the heaviest burden that the people of Australia bear in this regard. The figures--
—The Leader of the Opposition is their heaviest burden.

—I understand that he is but Mr Hayden need not blush because of that. Quite honestly, Mr Wran is conscious of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, is his heaviest burden. He shows that in all of his actions. I am grateful for Senator Button's interjection. The fact is that I believe Senator Lajovic's figures are correct. They do indicate that the pattern now of a heavy fall away of employment in New South Wales is not unconnected with the imposts that the Labor Government is charging and this is against the fact that barely only a year ago the Labor Government in its policy speech said, of course, it would lead New South Wales into full employment.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will be aware of recent reports which indicate that 1,000 Aboriginal teachers will be required by the year 2000. Will the Minister indicate whether steps are being taken to create a situation in which more Aboriginal people will be channelled into the teaching area? What special aspects are being undertaken to provide for multilingual training so that communities which so desire can provide tuition for their children in both English and their traditional language?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware of the existence of the National Aboriginal Education Committee which advises officers of my Department on matters relating to Aboriginal education. Its Chairman, Mr John Budby, may well be known to the honourable senator. The target of 1,000 Aboriginal teachers by 1990 was derived from within the Aboriginal community, I think by the NAEC. It is certainly one which is being promoted by the NAEC. The proposition behind that target, namely that we require a large number of Aboriginal teachers, is one that is recognised by all those who are associated with Aboriginal education and with the needs for it. Many of the initiatives that need to be taken will need to be taken through my portfolio rather than through the portfolio of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, whom I represent.

ANSWER.PARA: For a start, there are questions of Abstudy grants being made available to those who might be suitable and who wish to be trained as Aboriginal teachers. Representations come to me as to more appropriate benefits which might enable mature age Aboriginals with family responsibilities to take on such training. That would require further consideration by government. But to the extent that Abstudy is involved, we are trying to do what we can to make sure that that grant is available to all of those who want to take on teaching courses. Increased numbers of Aboriginal people are entering courses. Secondly, we are trying to make sure that within most of the schools that take on teacher training there is a readiness to accept Aboriginal candidates. That kind of negotiation is going on. Thirdly, in terms of people who get on to campus, we try in many places to mount what are called enclave programs-I think the honourable senator will be familiar with the way in which they operate-whereby extra support is mounted around students, particularly Aboriginal students, to try to enable them to succeed. Without picking up the particular number, I assure the honourable senator that we understand the need for Aboriginal teachers to be available and for the training system to be responsive and sensitive.

The honourable senator referred particularly to bilingual teachers or teachers with capacities in more than one language. I will obtain for her the details of what we are doing in the bilingual area. This is an area of overlap with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I would want to have accurate details for her. We have something like 17 schools in the Northern Territory now offering bilingual programs. An increased training program is going on to try to get people who have bilingual capacities. I endorse the sentiment behind the honourable senator's question. I will try to obtain for her all the details of the ways in which we are trying to promote its achievement.

I will see that it is drawn to his attention.

—Will the Minister for Education inform the Senate what priority the Government places upon the introduction of mandatory second language instruction in Australian schools? The Minister will remember making some sympathetic remarks about this matter at an ethnic communities conference which he and I addressed in company with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. He will recall further being picked up last week by the ever astute Australian Associated Press when he gave me a crossed-fingers sign presumably indicating that these plans were well advanced in the Government. I ask further: Will the Minister indicate what plans, if any, exist for the introduction or extension of second language training in Australia's education system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very instructive experience for me last week, having listened to a speech by Senator Chipp without interjecting or saying a word, to see a Press report that I had taken a certain line of endorsement which put me in conflict with one of my colleagues. I found that very instructive.
—You did make a meaningful signal to me.

—So the Press reported. It is not for me to say what signals are meaningful. From now on, I am going to stand here with my hands clasped demurely in front of me. Senator Chipp's question concerned the priority and emphasis which the Government gives to mandatory second language instruction. I think the honourable senator will agree that it may not be appropriate for us to be proposing mandatory second language instruction. What I said in the speech to which the honourable senator referred at a recent conference on national language policy was that there are lots of benefits to Australia in having a polyglot community rather than a single language community and that there are many reasons why we, as a nation, should want to develop a capacity to be proficient in more than one language. I have no doubt about that. The Commonwealth does not administer or make day to day decisions in most of the education systems as the education systems in the States are run by the States. The Commonwealth administers the system in the Australian Capital Territory, which operates at a better level than most of the other systems. All we can do is to encourage the States to proceed down this road.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that we can help to establish within the national mind the desirability of pursuing a community more competent in languages, we are anxious to do so. I think the point that was made by Mr Hodges at that conference is valid; that is that the teaching of English remains a very high priority in this country and competence in English remains probably our first priority for many people who come here. That is not to say that we would not like to see most Australians competent in a second language. The honourable senator asked another question which I cannot recall. He might tell me the second half of his question by way of interjection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any plans before Cabinet to introduce this?

—I cannot discuss Cabinet matters here but I can say that I indicated at that conference that we were interested in getting the input from the conference and looking at the issues which are involved in doing the kinds of things I have just outlined and, at an appropriate time, an approach will be made to the government for decisions which relate to those matters. I cannot say any more than that for reasons that Senator Chipp will comprehend.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce and concerns the excess capacity of the world steel industry. Is it a fact that President Mitterrand has been unable to restore France's ailing steel industry notwithstanding his election promises of 18 months ago? Is it a fact that Japanese steel mills have recently made cutbacks in their steel production because they are unable to compete with the more modern steel mills of Korea? Will not the development of the new Bahrain pelleting plant currently under construction for Arab iron and steel add yet another nail to the coffin of ailing outdated steel works throughout the world? With that in the background, will the Minister say whether BHP intends to use the Federal Government's accelerated depreciation allowance package to modernise its steelworks so that they can once again become world competitive, or has BHP simply decided to give the game away? Finally, will the Government ensure that BHP workers are not fooled, in the Mitterrand fashion, into believing that there is any solution in increased protection, subsidies or nationalisation as an alternative to modernisation at least to the standards of steelworks in South Korea, Taiwan and Bahrain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is generally true that steel industries around the world, including those mentioned by Senator Lewis in his question, in France and Japan, are in significant difficulties and have reduced output. We are feeling the effect in Australia-not least in my part of Australia, Western Australia-in reduced purchases of the raw materials that we normally sell. I think it is true also that the establishment of new and highly efficient steel industries in other countries changes the terms of world competition. It is true that Australian steel producers, BHP in particular, are likely to find the world market more difficult given that new and modern plants are being brought into production.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think there would be any prospect of BHP giving the game away, as mentioned by Senator Lewis. It is my understanding that BHP is about to make a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission, which may indicate its future intentions with respect to steel production in Australia, but I know of no public statement by the company yet which would indicate that it is taking advantage of the improved depreciation arrangements which were introduced by the Government earlier this year-which were seen by some, I think, specifically as a BHP benefit-and engage in further modernisation. However, I shall check that with the Minister for Industry and Commerce and see whether a more detailed reply can be provided.

I have little doubt that the people who work for BHP would realise that their future security of employment is dependent upon there being a competitive industry in Australia, and that any short term protection is unlikely to give them the sort of long term security for which I am sure they wish. But again, I shall ask Mr Peacock whether he wishes to make any additional comment on the matters raised by Senator Lewis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It concerns the report in today's edition of the Australian that Mr Street, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, said of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and its criticism of the Philippine aid projects funded by Australia in North Samar:

QUESTION.PARA: I do not think there is any doubt at all that there is a high political content in a lot of the statements that have been made.

Is the Government there repeating the highly defamatory and destructive comment of the then Ambassador Woolcott of 21 April 1982 in the Philippines, in which he said that such criticism was provided 'mostly by some priests here and that it was disappointing, untrue and unjust' and 'ill-informed or politically motivated . . . emanating from a relatively small number of people'? Is the Government, either through its ambassadors or now through the Minister for Foreign Affairs, attempting to justify the continuous harassment of the poor and the oppressed and church workers aiding them in the Philippines and, in particular, is it continuing to justify aid programs which benefit the military in charge of that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I understand it, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace issued a media release on 16 November alleging that the Australian Government had assisted the Philippine Government's alleged repression of Catholic clergy in the Philippines. The allegation was based on an assertion that a speech by the then Ambassador in Manila, Mr Woolcott, in April 1982, referred to the role of politically motivated priests in supplying information to foreign critics on Australian aid. It is alleged that this comment and subsequent media coverage of criticism by priests in the Philippines of an Australian project on the island of Samar touched off a series of violations of human rights on Samar partly directed against clergy. Regarding the allegation of a linkage between Mr Woolcott's remarks in April and the alleged campaign of repression in October-November, there is no evidence of any such connection. Criticism by the clergy of such projects as those to which Mr Woolcott referred has long been public knowledge in the Philippines. There is also no evidence that any of the recent actions by the Philippine Government is motivated simply by a desire to stifle critics of foreign aid projects.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked questions by other honourable senators with regard to aid to the Philippines. On behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs I want to make a fairly general comment. The Australian Government is always concerned about violations of human rights, wherever they occur. The Government's position on internationally accepted standards of human rights has been repeated in a number of international forums and is well known, including by the Philippines Government. Australia, bearing in mind its own national interests and the interests of the recipient country, does provide development assistance and co- operation. The granting of aid by Australia does not necessarily imply, on the part of either Australia or any recipient country, endorsement of the other's policies. This applies generally and therefore also applies in the case of the Philippines. The Australian Government does not believe it would be appropriate to link the Australian Development Assistance Program to the human rights question in the Philippines. I will have what was said yesterday by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, which Senator Tate has mentioned, related to the question that has been directed to me today, to see whether the Minister wishes to make any further comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the page 1 article in this mornings's Adelaide Advertiser with the headline 'Stores expect a happy Christmas. Shoppers start buying spree' been drawn to the Minister's attention? In particular, the article states:

QUESTION.PARA: Both Woolworths (SA) Ltd and Myer (SA) Stores Ltd. Management agreed that tax concessions introduced on November 1 had gone a long way towards increasing consumer confidence and spending.
According to the writer, the manager of Harris Scarfe Ltd has said:
. . . despite the drought affecting rural communities, country orders also were excellent.
The article also states:
. . . increases in child endowment had meant families had more cash in their hands to spend.
I ask the Minister: Is the Budget having its intended effect of boosting retail sales and consumer confidence in the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the article referred to by Senator Teague. I do not know whether it has been drawn to the attention of the Treasurer. No doubt during the next month or so we will see statements regarding the effect on retail sales and on the confidence of consumers. I think the benefits mentioned by Senator Teague, that flowed from the August Budget, have undoubtedly improved the facility of many families to spend on things that they need or desire for themselves and their families. I hope, in the interests of economic activity, that retail selling in the next month or two will be healthy and that there will be in the community resources to ensure that such activity is increased to the greatest degree possible. I do not know whether I need refer to the Treasurer anything raised by Senator Teague, but I am sure that he will have presented to him during the next month statistics with regard to consumer activity.

—I remind the Leader of the Government in the Senate that in the last two weeks he has made numerous references to the danger and irresponsibility of too large a deficit. What, in his view and in the view of the Government, is the upper limit for a safe and responsible deficit for this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the ideal situation is to have as small a deficit as possible. That is a view of this Government that, of course, the Australian Labor Party opposes. Within the Labor Party there is a wide divergence of opinion on the subject. For example, Mr Hawke holds the view that a considerably larger deficit than is favoured by Mr Hayden would be appropriate . The Government gave an indication of the kind of deficit that it expected. Unfortunately, arising out of events subsequent to the Budget-drought relief plus the unemployment factors that have emerged-expenditure has increased. The optimum deficit is one that we can control within those limits. We put no ceiling on it because no one can measure the extent of the drought. The fact is that the drought and its extent are beyond our control. Therefore, we cannot measure precisely the amount of money that will be involved in the extension of the Budget. But we will try to keep the Budget deficit as small as we possibly can.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. In view of his numerous statements prior to, during the presentation of and since the Budget, regarding the irresponsibility of large deficits-he has avoided answering my question-I ask him to spell out as precisely as he can what he believes to be a responsible deficit in view of all the things that have happened in the last few weeks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat what I have said. The Budget was based on a deficit which the Government regarded as responsible. To it must be added those absolutely essential additions caused by drought and additional unemployment. But there should be a major control of the deficit and no unnecessary expenditure because we do not want to accelerate inflation or interest rates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney- General whether he noted the Press statement released, I think, last Thursday in Adelaide by the Australian Police Ministers' Council and whether he noted the contents which in part read:

QUESTION.PARA: The States and the Northern Territory note with extreme concern the unilateral action of the Commonwealth in proceeding with legislation for a Commonwealth crimes commission. In expressing this view the States and the Northern Territory record that all States and the Northern Territory are working with the Commonwealth through the Australian Police Ministers' Council and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to undertake genuinely national co-operative measures to deal effectively with identified problems of organised crimes? It is the view of the States and the Northern Territory that the crimes commission, as proposed, will not be effective.

Given that the great majority of crime falls under State and Northern Territory legislation, will the Government consider holding over the National Crimes Commission legislation until the next session of Parliament in the new year to allow for proper co-operative negotiations and arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth to ensure that the legislation reflects the views of the States and the Commonwealth and will properly fight organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of great regret for me that I did not see the statement referred to but I am sure that it will be drawn to my attention and that I will have the chance to see the views expressed by the Police Ministers' Council. The idea that the States traditionally are responsible for criminal law , in the sense in which criminal law is generally understood, should not lead one to the conclusion to which Senator Crichton-Browne seems to have come that there are no significant areas of Commonwealth responsibility in which there is criminal activity. If one thinks of the fields of taxation or Customs, one immediately thinks of a couple of fertile fields in which organised crime can flourish. Nobody could look at the reports which have been coming down for 10 years, which show not just episodic crime which occurs when somebody is a naughty boy, but crime which occurs on a broad basis by people scheming to defraud the whole community; nobody could look at the lack of action which has occurred among State police forces with respect to organised crime; and nobody could look at chapter 10 of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which was tabled in this place and which talked about the scope of organised crime and the inability of the State police forces to come to grips with it, without being deeply disturbed.

ANSWER.PARA: When significant areas of Commonwealth responsibility are involved and significant areas of Commonwealth law can be flouted by organised crime, I do not believe it is possible for the Commonwealth simply to stand back and say that organised crime is a matter which is fundamentally one of State responsibility. The Commonwealth has made clear that it wishes to enter into this matter on a co-operative basis with the States but that it believes that a crimes commission is needed. In those circumstances, of course co-operation is a two-way process. We have legislation which will be debated in this place shortly which permits co-operative action between the Commonwealth and the States. If that co-operation is not forthcoming-indeed, we hope and expect that it will be- it provides for a commission which can deal with those areas of specific Commonwealth responsibility. In other words, the Commission would be charged with looking merely at those areas of Commonwealth law which might be flouted by organised crime.

I think this matter is of general public concern. We should come to grips with something which successive reports, culminating in the Costigan report, have shown us do exist in our community. I hope that the States will see fit to pick up the opportunity for co-operation with the Commonwealth which exists in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Having heard the Minister acknowledge the concerns expressed to ensure that there is a proper battle against organised crime, will he concede that excellent progress was being made by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Police Ministers Council prior to the unilateral decision of the Commonwealth Government to proceed with this legislation? Does the Minister concede that the battle against organised crime will be more effective, more powerful and more persuasive if there is proper co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States to ensure we have the sort of legislation that the Minister indicated is required?

—I certainly agree that one will get a more effective attack on organised crime if the Commonwealth and the States co-operate in that effort. As I tried to make clear in my answer, however, if that co-operation is not forthcoming then the Commonwealth will remain resolute in its wish to come to grips with organised crime which affects areas of clear Commonwealth responsibility. With regard to the co-operative arrangements which were being discussed at the meetings in September, the fact is that the States had a quite separate proposition which involved the strengthening of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, a body which has been established for some time and which already operates on a co-operative Commonwealth-State basis. As was made clear to the States when the Commonwealth indicated in October that it intended to proceed with the establishment of the National Crimes Commission, the Commonwealth is still prepared to see the criminal intelligence arrangements strengthened in the way which is wanted by the States. There is no barrier at all to the continued development of that further co-operative effort to increase both Commonwealth and State resources in the attack on organised crime.

—Before calling further questions I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of a delegation from the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China. The delegation is led by Vice-Chairman Zhu Xuefan of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend to you , Sir, and to your delegates a very warm welcome to Australia, to this city and to this chamber in particular. We trust that you will all have a most enjoyable and worthwhile visit to Australia.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: If, as the Government now suggests, a wages freeze is the formula needed to solve the problem of inflation and unemployment, why did not the Government try to initiate a freeze last year instead of abandoning any wages policy and declaring that market forces alone should apply? Why did the Liberal-National Country Party Opposition, of which the present Leader of the Government was a prominent member, so vigorously oppose the referendum put forward by the Labor Government on wage and price control in 1974?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren has asked two separate questions. It so happens that in the course of last year the wage upsurge-it caused the devastation which we now face-was something like 17 per cent to 18 per cent. It is because of that upsurge that a wage freeze is necessary. The fact is that it is now that the visible impact of those wage increases is causing the shedding of employment in companies and, of course, threatening future jobs that it is necessary to act. I would have thought that that was clear. The Government parties in 1974 made clear throughout Australia their views in opposing the referendum of that time. Those views are well known. They were reflected very strongly in the ballot box by the people. I have no doubt that that support is similar to the support that the people would have for that proposal today. The sovereign powers with respect to prices lie with the States. The States have the power to act if they so desire.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. It was announced early last week that the Industries Assistance Commission will be holding an inquiry into the sugar industry. The terms of reference are reported to be wide ranging. Because of considerable interest being displayed in developing a sugar industry in northern Western Australia and because of requests from Queensland that the Commonwealth should refuse to issue export licences for sugar from the Ord region, will this inquiry look at the powers of the Commonwealth under sections 92 and 99 of the Constitution to act in this way?

—The IAC may well choose to refer to the constitutional provisions , although I cannot see that that would advance the matter very far. I think what has been made clear-I think this is a significant response to the point of concern to Senator Thomas-is that the Commonwealth Government is well aware of the responsibilities which it carries under section 99 of the Constitution not to discriminate against any particular part of Australia. Clearly, whatever provisions are made in the future with respect to a sugar industry, they will have to be area neutral-in other words, they will have to be provisions which apply equally to all regions of Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the difficulty found by local government and other organisations which employ children's services development officers with assistance from Commonwealth funding. I ask the Minister: Has the Government made a decision as to the future of this funding which is guaranteed only until the end of this year? What are the employment prospects of these officers at the end of this year which is, after all, only six weeks away?

—It was my understanding that there had been some extension of that period, but I will have to check that. The conditions for the future employment of children's services development officers were considered earlier this year. I think notice was given in the past of the conditions under which they would be appointed. This is something of a regional concern. The great bulk of CSDOs are employed in Victoria. I forget the exact figures but almost the whole of the number that are subsidised by the Commonwealth are employed in that one State. The precise conditions are not a matter which I have clearly enough in my memory to hazard a guess at. I will bring further information to the Senate in response to the honourable senator's question. The general concern is that the arrangements for the employment of CSDOs should be such that they are engaged in productive work which will improve access to children's services and in appropriate areas improve the supply of subsidised places. I will go back to the papers, which I have not looked at for some months now, and let Senator Grimes have a further reply to his question.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources: Is he happy about the working of the fast track anti-dumping legislation? Were not the taking of cash securities and the speedy resolution of dumping allegations raised as forceful arguments by the chief negotiator, Mr Anderson, in selling the benefits of closer economic relations to Australians who were concerned about the inflow of subsidised goods from New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter that needs specific information. I will refer it to the responsible Minister and seek an answer.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Government, in its proposed wage freeze, assessed that a freeze on Commonwealth, State and local government salaries would mean an overall saving of expenditure of about $700m? If so, can the Minister say how this is broken up as far as Commonwealth, State and local government public services are concerned? In view of the importance of local government payrolls to communities in country towns, is the Minister aware that there is great concern in those areas that the Government's proposal will have a serious deleterious effect on the economies of those towns, particularly in view of the critical drought situation that exists in New South Wales and its consequential effect on the economies of country areas, to which Senator Sibraa and I can testify from our inspection of certain rural areas in our State last weekend?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —With reference to the latter part of the question, the Government has been acutely conscious of the conditions in various country districts and towns. Of course, because of the Government's understanding of the position, it has embarked on a very widespread, I think unprecedented, support for drought relief to the extent that it is envisaged that there should be perhaps some $350m for drought relief made available. That of course would help to offset the hardships in those places. I have not the precise breakup of the $700m. I will seek that for the honourable senator. The fact is that the aim not only with the saving of the $700m but also with savings in commerce and industry throughout the community is to recycle the money to provide further employment opportunities for people and therefore to offset the drought effect. It is not intended to reduce the volume of money in the community at all. The intent is to keep the money recycled and to provide for more employment than if wage rises were to persist. There ought to be no fall-off at all in purchasing power; on the contrary, it should be maintained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Leader of the Government in the Senate saw an article in last Saturday's Weekend Australian in which the secretary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, Mr Joseph Luns, is reported as having said:

QUESTION.PARA: Moscow is 'strongly aiding and abetting' peace movements in the west which, advocating a nuclear freeze, are seriously threatening attempts to install new US missiles in Western Europe.
I ask whether the Leader agrees with Mr Luns and with Mr Luns's further reported comment that it was his opinion:
'. . . that this peace movement has been strongly promoted by the Soviet Union' .
Mr Luns is also reported as having said:
Furthermore, I believe those who want unilateral disarmament on our side are aiding the Soviet Union.

Has the Minister seen any evidence recently in Australia that much the same thing is going on here? Would the anti-Omega demonstration at the weekend have been part of the communist suckers' activities-'suckers' as in 'gullible'-which assist the Soviet? Is the Leader of the Government aware that communist peacefront activities in Australia have been exposed in a brilliant article in a recent issue of the excellent magazine Quadrant? Does the Leader of the Government agree with President Reagan who said recently that Soviet agents were infiltrating Western groups and pushing for nuclear freeze and disarmament by the West? Finally, will the Government issue a warning, friendly or otherwise, to the Australian community to beware of bears in merino skins which although they may look cuddly, are always on the lookout for an easy meal of gullible Australian suckers-some of whom are to be found on the other side of this chamber-who want peace at any price?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see such an article in the Weekend Australian referring to the NATO Secretary-General. I can understand the concern of NATO that there should be attempts to achieve unilateral disarmament by the Western free world forces because, of course, unilateral disarmament could threaten the peace of the world. What is needed is multilateral disarmament and what this Government and the governments of the free world are working for is a multilateral putting down of arms so we can live at peace together. Of course, those movements that advocate unilateral disarmament may in some cases be advocating that with the best of intentions; in other cases, they could be advocating this with subversive intent. The honourable senator asked about the Omega demonstration. I cannot believe that there can exist an Australian who believes that Omega offers any defence or military threat to Australia. No thinking Australian-indeed, no member of this Parliament-could do so, because the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence--
—I do. Don't speak for me.

—With the greatest of respect, I refer to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on which Senator Primmer sat and which found-let me make it perfectly clear-that Omega is a navigation aid for ordinary peace time purposes and is incapable of being used in a war-time situation because there is no master station but eight individual stations around the world, some in the free world and some in Iron Curtain countries. Any one of those stations is capable of being turned off by the country in which it is situated so that it is prevented from being a defence weapon.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Primmer that the Committee found on scientific evidence that no nuclear submarine would ever navigate by Omega because, as a result of electrical storms and solar flares, it could be totally inaccurate. Indeed, he will be reminded that a great deal of the time of that Committee was spent on determining that submarines carrying ballistic missiles navigate both by their submarine inertial navigation systems and by using transit satellites. Fundamentally and essentially that Committee found that there is no way at all in which Omega would be used in a military sense, that those who sought to use it in a military sense would be using a very inaccurate and unreliable mechanism , and that it is good for commercial navigation.

I can only say that those who are leading the anti-Omega movement are misleading the public. The sooner the people of Australia understand the truth about Omega-that it is not in any way a military weapon-the more sensible we will be about it. It is regrettable that we cannot get at this moment multilateral disarmament in the world. We should all work towards it. That ought to be our goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to a report in today's Australian Financial Review that the Government is reviewing the levy arrangements for crude oil? Is the Government in fact reviewing the pricing and levy arrangements for domestically-produced crude oil? Does this review also include a review of the arrangements whereby some oil fields are classified as new fields and some as old fields? Does this review also include a review of the Government's previous decision not to levy products from the Fortescue oil field?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in the Australian Financial Review. The report is based on wrong information.
—The same as the editorial last week.

—I can understand the Australian Labor Party's sensitivity to Australian Financial Review editorials. Let me direct myself to Senator Sibraa's question. The only matter the Government is directing itself to at the moment is what are called black holes in the exploration sense. There are classifications of small, medium and large fields and a different levy is charged on each. There is a problem when a well produces more than, shall we say , two million barrels and gets into a higher payment category. Contrary to the newspaper story, the Government did not take the initiative on this. The producers have asked the government whether it will look to this question of what are called black holes in the jargon of the exploration and development trade so that they can have charges which would not penalise them should they move from, shall we say, a small field to a middle-sized field or from a middle sized field to a large field. This is under review at the moment. In any attempt to do that, whatever happens, the Government will seek to get from the producers in those fields only the same amount of money as it gets today. We do not at this moment have anything else under review.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to an article by Mr Arthur Faulkner and Mr Des Storer which appeared in a recent addition of Migrant Action and which related to the evaluation undertaken by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs of the report of the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants. Will the Minister comment on the claims by Mr Faulkner and Mr Storer that if a substantial piece of research conducted by the Institute to support its evaluation-namely, the survey of information, needs and use of services-is as described, there is probably no other comparable study in this area and that, if published, it would possibly be more significant than the evaluation itself? In view of the significance of this survey, which was a sample of some 1,760 non -English speaking migrants in areas of Sydney and Melbourne, I ask the Minister: Firstly, why has the survey not been published; and, secondly, will the survey of information, needs and use of services be published to enable a full and open debate on what social and welfare services are needed by migrants in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs did see the claim made by Mr Faulkner and Mr Storer with regard to the survey of information. I think the Minister's reaction to that report was that it was erroneous in some sense because the survey was only one part of the work that was done for the evaluation. The evaluation was a major and far-reaching review of the implementation of the Galbally report and it made about 89 recommendations. The Government will spend about $21m over three years as a result of the additional direct cost of the package of measures recommended.

ANSWER.PARA: The claim made in the article could not be sustained. The assertion made by the authors is even more surprising, given the advice provided to me by the Minister that on 31 August this year Mr Storer was given a copy of the survey questionnaire and a full briefing on the survey by the Institute and he was advised that frequency distributions of responses and detailed statistical analysis of each question would be provided. Mr Storer advised that he would write specifying what data, if any, would be required. I understand that the Institute has not subsequently received any request for data from him.

With regard to publication, the Institute has followed the normal practice of describing the methodology of the survey referred to and relevant findings in its published report, the 'Evaluation of Post-Arrival Programs and Services'. Furthermore, the questionnaire and the additional information on the methodology and frequency distribution of responses are available on request. Access to the raw data is not provided at present as the Institute is continuing to use it, but when the analysis is complete the data will be placed in a suitable data bank with appropriate provision to ensure the confidentiality of the respondents . Until that time the Institute will meet reasonable requests for analysis of the data and the only costs will be those of the staff and the computer time involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to reports that the Western Australian Government has decided to proceed with a sugar scheme on the Ord River. Does the Federal Government consider that this will have serious ramifications for Australia in its negotiations to attempt to control the world-wide sugar glut, in particular the seven million tonnes surplus in the European Economic Community? Does the Minister not agree that Australia can hardly ask the EEC to cut back on sugar production acreage while Australia is expanding its own?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious from the questions one is asked in this place that there is a certain element of State bias involved in where the questions come from. Western Australian senators are likely to be very keen to see that Western Australia's right to have a sugar industry is preserved and Queensland senators are likely to be very keen to see the existing industry is preserved. The position of the Commonwealth Government is that it cannot favour one geographic area of the country over another. There is an international sugar glut at the moment; that is absolutely true. There is a supported price within Australia and a lower export price. If another industry is developed in another part of Australia difficult negotiations will be involved in establishing what export quantities and what domestic quantities will be available to the various industries in the different parts of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation of the sugar industry is not static. At the moment there is a world surplus and, consequently, the world price is low. That is unlikely to be a permanent state of affairs. In any event, I will ask the Minister for Primary Industry to consider the point which has been raised by the honourable senator in his question. But I do not believe that the question contains the seeds of a solution to the dispute currently going on within Australia about where we should and should not have sugar industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the first national conference on industrial safety was held in Sydney last week? Has he had his attention drawn to the statements made at that conference by the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Justice Kirby, that industrial accidents caused at least 300 deaths and 300 disabling injuries in Australia each year, resulting in the loss of about one million working weeks; that the national reaction to daily evidence of the lack of work safety was one of indifference, resignation and buck-passing; that new laws on occupational health and safety were needed in Australia; and that initiatives taken overseas should be considered? When will this Government take positive steps towards preventing the terrible toll in industrial accidents which not only kill and maim but also waste more money than is spent annually on the national defence budget?

—The honourable senator consistently draws the attention of the community and the Government to the great waste involved in industrial accidents. I have not seen a report of the conference of last week or of Mr Justice Kirby's statements, but I am sure that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations would have seen those comments. Within the last month or so I have noted that Mr Macphee in fact has made some public comments which very much pick up the sort of point made by the honourable senator in his question. I will refer the question to Mr Macphee and ask him to give a reply to it.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that the Minister for Health is proposing to change the organisation of the Department of Health to two divisions-a management group and a policy group- which will dramatically reduce the input from the principal bodies involved in the delivery of health services? Is the Minister aware that, whilst all interested parties were invited to comment on the present Department, they have been given no opportunity to comment on the proposed reorganisation? Does the Minister not agree that it would be a matter of prudence and of courtesy for at least the representative bodies of Australia's two greatest health professions, the Australian Medical Association and the Australian Dental Association, to be invited to comment on this matter? Will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the effectiveness of the National Health and Medical Research Council in providing support for medical research in Australia will not be severely compromised by these changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had brought to my attention any detailed proposals for reorganisation within the Department of Health. I imagine, though , that appropriate consultations would take place if, in fact, such arrangements were proposed. As a matter of fact, I have just had handed to me by my staff a Press statement from the Minister whom I represent in this place which could contain some information concerning management changes in the Department of Health. Of course, honourable senators would be interested in knowing that there is to be a new Director-General of Health from 1 January 1983. Mr Laurie Willett will replace Dr Howells, who will stand down at that time. It may well be that that will be an appropriate moment for Mr Carlton to examine a range of management matters. I cannot imagine that Mr Carlton would undertake such an exercise without having the consultations to which Senator MacGibbon has referred in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: Specifically in relation to the National Health and Medical Research Council, I do have a little more information. Although I have not heard anything from the Minister which would indicate what his intentions might be nor, as far as I know, has the Government considered any such proposals, I have had as a senator a number of inputs from organisations concerned that there may be changes in the offing which they would regard as disadvantageous to themselves. I have had inputs from bodies representing medical research, the medical professions, dentistry and so on which are anxious lest their role be diminished. I believe that Mr Carlton would be very much aware of, and sensitive to, these representations, and if he were proposing changes to the NH and MRC-which has, by the way, a very proud record in Australian research-he would do so only after appropriate consultation. Of course, in the end he would, I imagine, seek the advice of his colleagues in government in respect of any such arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I was to produce a report from the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. We are waiting for the report to reach the Parliament and I will seek leave to make such a statement when that document arrives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to defer consideration of my motion on this matter until later this week. I seek leave so to do.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.
—I want to know what we are going to do for the rest of the week.
—I seek leave to make a statement on this matter because I think that Senator Harradine is entitled to information on the subject .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Speaker of the House of Representatives has been advised that the House of Representatives will resume on Wednesday 8 December for the further consideration of its business. That will , of course, consist of business that may arise from this Senate and also any subsequent business that may come to hand including matters that may arise out of the Premiers Conference. That being so, this Senate will certainly need to meet in the week commencing 7 December and almost certainly the week commencing 14 December. In accordance with the generally expressed wish of all honourable senators, with a view to setting a timetable I advise that I will be moving that the Senate at its rising at the end of this week meet again on Tuesday, 7 December. In other words, in accordance with the ordinary cycle, next week will be an up week.
—Why don't you do it right now?

—I had the statement ready to make later today. It is only that a procedural matter came in hand. Because honourable senators are entitled to understand the whole of this matter, I advise the Senate that a considerable amount of work still needs to be done. I propose by discussion with honourable senators of all parties and the Independent senator to see just how much of this work we can complete by the end of this week. The proposal, therefore, envisages the sitting on Friday. Because the discussions are not complete I have deferred the moving of my motion until their completion. I now notify the Senate that following its rising at the end of this week it will resume on Tuesday, 7 December, at 1.45 p.m. That means that in the ordinary cycle of three weeks next week will be a week in which the Senate will not sit. I urge upon the Senate that because of the very heavy nature of the business that is before it now it should complete as much of the work as it possibly can by the time it rises at the end of this week. It will have new work ahead of it on 7 December.

—by leave-I take to heart the words of the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick) in which he said that he will consult with members of the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Independent senator. Quite frankly, we in the Labor Party are not impressed with the apparent necessity for the Senate to sit this Friday. TALK.START.PARA: —Look at McLaren.
—McLaren is getting jealous.

—Certain senators salivate when the Bounty (Berry Fruits) Bill comes up. So they should; they are important Bills to certain senators. There are Bills for passage if time permits. —I believe that Senator Sir John Carrick owes that courtesy to the Senate. I would not suspect for a moment that it is because the Labor Party has said that it will give them an easy passage. (a) condemns the abject failure of the Treasurer and the Government, knowing of the existence of straw company tax evasion schemes since at least 1978, to respond quickly and effectively to the massive tax evasion occurring through the use of such schemes;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are continuing the debate on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982. In speaking to this tax recoupment legislation today I wish to voice my sincere regret about the questionable concept of retrospectivity contained in it. To me the principle of retrospectivity is wrong. Along with every other pay-as-you-earn taxpayer-there are millions of them-I condemn the use of illegal schemes to evade taxes due, but I cannot agree with the use of retrospective legislation in order to recoup moneys that the Government says were due and should have been paid. That is, for me, a matter of principle and I cannot allow principles to be relinquished for the sake of expediency. People entered into taxation arrangements in good faith. They were advised by their accountants that they were legal and, according to the law at that time, they were otherwise why do we have this present legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: I have also heard it argued that the arrangements were illegal. If they were illegal a law must have been breached. Why were the offenders not prosecuted at that time? Current year profit schemes are included. I would like to know how something that was accepted according to the law at that time can now in retrospect be considered wrong? If the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes operated outside the limits of the law and if the Australian Taxation Office officials knew about them, why were the people concerned not brought to justice at the time? Whose fault is it? One thing we want to remember is that even if the tax was not paid to the tax man it has not been left sitting in banks. I am sure that it would have been spent, thus providing jobs and job opportunities for many people.

Proponents of the legislation claim fairness to the rest of the Australian people as the reason for it. One could say that that too is a very reasonable argument but do we think about fairness in other areas? People who are on average weekly earnings might wonder if fairness also applies in the case of superannuation schemes particularly those relating to members of parliament and senior public servants. A law has been invoked to enable large sums of public money to be paid to members of parliament and senior public servants and the bulk of that, of course, is not taxable. One might ask: In another sense is that not a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme? It enables a small group of people to benefit from the public purse without having to pay tax on the bulk of the money . This is legal, it was made respectable by an Act of Parliament. What about fairness in having family trusts by means of which income can be divided and less tax paid? It is not only big business that is trying to avoid tax; everyone wants to pay as little tax as possible and therefore tries to minimise the amount that has to be paid.

There is also the question of fairness in relation to the black cash economy which is flourishing in Australia. However, I point out that the Government has tried to reduce the vast amount lost to revenue through the cash economy. Despite this, many thousands of skilled tradesmen and labourers, as well as professional people, prefer to be paid in cash and so avoid tax. Is that fair to the rest of the Australian people? The evidence of widespread tax avoidance, such as we have in Australia, is to me the most damning evidence that it is the system, not the taxpayer, which stands in need of radical reform. I agree with Senator MacGibbon who said that what we need is simpler tax legislation. At one stage I suggested to a meeting at which I was speaking that I felt that the tax Acts should also be taken to the bottom of the harbour.

The 12 volumes which comprise our present tax laws do not compare very favourably with the 127 pages which make up Hong Kong's ordinances and regulations. I might add that Hong Kong has a flourishing economy despite the simplicity of its tax laws. For many companies and investors the necessity to resort to tax evasion and avoidance schemes simply reflects how far they are forced to go in order to obtain a reasonable return, providing they do it within the law. People in companies pay double taxation. Firstly, they pay 46 per cent company tax and then they have to pay tax on their dividends. So for the normal investor there is very little return from the company.

I think the Government should give some real thought to supporting initiative and drive in this country instead of stifling it through the crippling burden of taxation, especially double taxation. As recently as last Friday week I addressed a gathering of about 300 businessmen and women in Brisbane on the need for a complete overhaul of the tax system and the benefits of a single rate of tax. If we had a reasonable rate of tax I do not think people would feel the need to go to accountants and lawyers to see how they could minimise their taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Legally.

—Legally, that is right. I have spoken about this previously in the Senate. At present, the more one works the more tax one has to pay. People these days do not seem to want to work overtime because they say that if they do the Government will take the great percentage of it in tax. Where people are willing to work extra time, the Government should give thought to reducing the amount of tax that they have to pay. The Government should also seek to have as its prime objective as low a tax rate as possible so that business can grow, develop, thrive and thus give employment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that excessive tax destroys incentive. I consider that retrospective legislation can destroy business confidence. I hope that the passing of this tax recoupment legislation will not mean the collapse of many businesses and investments and the loss of many more jobs. All the present situation is doing, with tax avoidance schemes, bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, current year profit schemes and retrospective legislation, is locking taxpayers and government in a useless, time wasting and costly struggle which is breeding a mounting attitude of hostility to both government and the law which has already harmed us all.

One angle I would like to put is: If we cannot trust the law as it stands, whom or what can we trust? We must be able to rely on the law. When we ask for legal advice we must be able to believe it and feel that it will not be changed retrospectively. The ability to trust the law distinguishes our country from countries such as Russia or other communist countries where land can be taken away from people and they can be put in gaol without any worry about the law.

Another angle to this debate is: Is this retrospective legislation really necessary? People have already been charged under the existing legislation and the prosecutor appointed by the Government has not yet got going. I consider that there should have been some test cases under the existing legislation before the Government contemplated moving with its proposed legislation. Does the end justify the means? In recovering vast amounts of money, will the Government feel justified in opening up a Pandora's box for others to abuse indiscriminately? Let us not be naive enough to think that it could not happen. Recently in New South Wales Mr Wran and his Government talked about introducing legislation that would collect unpaid stamp duty on any transaction as far back as 1920-62 years ago. Fortunately that idea appears to have been shelved.

There was also talk that Mr Cain and his Government in Victoria were considering a retrospective land tax. Who knows what retrospectivity might be introduced federally? What worries me is that our Government may give justification for retrospectivity. One could think, of course, about how quickly it might be abused and what might be in store for us. As a matter of fact, Senator Evans himself has said that this legislation will be only the thin end of the wedge if the Labor Party ever gets into power. He said that a Labor government would introduce more, and worse, retrospective legislation.

There are too many aspects of this legislation with question marks. Many people say that it is badly drafted legislation and is wrong in its fundamental aim. I consider that there is a need for an innocence clause. I will be supporting this in the Committee stage. There are vendor-shareholders who dealt with purchasers who were not involved in the bottom-of-the-harbour or other fraudulent schemes and who can produce documentary or other substantive evidence that they took all reasonable steps to ensure that the law would not be breached either by themselves or by the purchaser. The subsequent actions of the purchaser proved this to be correct. The subject company also conformed to all taxation and companies Acts at all times. Unfortunately, the legislation as tabled extends to cover such innocent vendor-shareholders. I do not feel that the legislation was ever intended to be so extensive. The least the Government can do is to exempt such innocent vendor-shareholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you reckon that they are innocent?

—Yes, I certainly do. I feel sorry that the Government has seen fit to introduce this legislation which includes the retrospective concept in order to collect tax that it says should have been paid. I repeat that I do not condone the use of tax evasion schemes but I cannot accept, now or in the future, the principle of retrospectivity that we find in these tax recoupment Bills. Therefore, I will not be able to support the legislation when the vote is taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded from time to time in the tax debate of the saying that no matter how complex an issue may be one can be sure that someone will come up with a solution which is clear, simple and wrong. I am reminded of that particularly when people suggest that the solution to the great tax evasion industry that we have in this country, in common with other countries, is a simple system of tax. I am particularly dismayed when Hong Kong is given as an example that we ought to be following. I have had the opportunity to visit Hong Kong and I know a little about it. Whilst there are many things about that colony's economy which are admirable in terms of productivity and growth, there are other things about it which I am sure we would not want to see in this country. We would certainly not want to see the lack of security in old age or in infirmity that can exist in that colony.

SPEECH.PARA: There are those who campaign for a lower rate of tax-a so-called 'flat tax'-as a solution to the problem that we face at the moment. More than once in the Senate they have given that as an example. Whilst I join with such people in their opposition to this retrospective legislation, I do not think that to prescribe Hong Kong's social standards and welfare standards is any solution at all to the situation that we face. The simple fact is that a flat rate of tax-a 20c in the dollar tax, as is suggested-means that poorer people would pay more tax or else fewer facilities would be available to deserving citizens in this country. I have had this proposition put to me many times around my electorate. Unfortunately, those who propose it to me are the same people who are likely to say how much more government assistance is necessary for export incentives; how much more money should be spent on our roads, particularly in central and northern Queensland; and how much more money should be given in benefits of one sort or another in which they are interested.

I am convinced that in the context of the whole tax evasion or tax lowering debate there are people in our community, a small but vocal percentage, who just do not want to pay any tax at all. It would not matter whether tax was 20c in the dollar or 90c in the dollar; they would have the same complaint. The people who are evading paying tax now, whether they be paying 46c in the dollar or 60c in the dollar, would evade paying tax at 20c in the dollar. The simple situation is that there are in our community people who do not believe in paying tax, who believe that if they can avoid paying tax-however they may avoid it-that is a fair gain. There are people who feel no responsibility at all to pay tax. I believe it is a citizen's duty and responsibility to make a contribution of some sort, provided that he or she can afford to make one, to the mutual needs of the community whether those needs be roads, hospitals or defence forces. They are all things that the nation needs. They are all things which we should all, as citizens, be prepared to support if we possibly can.

That is, of course, what is so nauseous about the tax evasion debate. I, along with many others in this chamber in recent years, have felt nauseated as we have heard conversations or read claims in newspapers about how one is a mug if one pays tax and how, if one is not onto this lurk or that lurk it just serves one right. We have been asked 'Have you heard the latest one?' and 'What is the name of your tax accountant?' So this situation has gone on for years. Frankly, that is one of the reasons that I find this initiative by the Government unacceptable . We have all known for some time that the tax evasion industry was a very large and a growing one. We should in this context, however, give credit to the Government for those moves towards tax evasion which have been real.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards stopping tax evasion.
—I am sorry, I meant towards stopping tax evasion. The Minister correctly points out that in my agitation on this subject I made a minor slip of the tongue.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all aware also of the flat statements by those involved in taxation, particularly taxation accountants-that the initiatives of John Howard and of the Fraser Government have virtually stamped out tax evasion in this country. The sadness of the situation we find ourselves in now is that action that should have been taken several years ago in relation to this instance-the bottom-of-the -harbour schemes-was not effectively taken at the time. Therefore, we are faced with the odious business of establishing retrospective taxation legislation. It is odious. It has been an unsavoury debate, which has now been going on for several months in one way or another.

I personally have not publicly entered the debate until this moment. When I was pressed, some months ago, by certain people to state my position in relation to the legislation I refused to state a position because I wanted to see what Bill I would actually be voting on when I was finally required to indicate what my position was. I hoped, as many others did, that there would be some modification of the legislation, that the legislation would not be so extreme. But the situation has been inflamed in a variety of ways. It has not been helped by certain newspaper editorials which have stated that anybody in Parliament who opposes the retrospective tax legislation cannot avoid what the newspaper editorials claim is a condoning of tax evasion, avoidance, cheating-call it whatever you like-people trying to get out of paying the tax that they should pay on the incomes that they are receiving. I utterly reject that allegation.

I, as I have already indicated, am someone who firmly believes it is a citizen' s duty to make his or her contribution through tax in its various forms to the welfare of the general community. We can debate the degree of need but I do not accept that anyone can avoid saying that we have a mutual responsibility to our nation in that area. However, it is a giant step to say that any form of tax recoupment or collection is therefore justified if it is aimed at catching up with those who have had some advantage in the past. Any method is not justified. I think this legislation will bring about a chaotic situation at a time, frankly , when the nation really cannot afford it in some areas.

I do not condone the fact that it is alleged that the Gold Coast building boom is due, at least in part, to money that was evaded through these bottom-of-the- harbour schemes. It seems to me, in my basic approach to taxation legislation, that the genuine bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, the destruction of company records as a means to avoid paying tax, must surely be illegal and must surely have been illegal. There are some opinions that indicate that it has been believed to be illegal, but action has not been taken. It is not good enough for me-much as it pains me to criticise my own Government on this issue-when it can be claimed that this legislation is an attempt to avoid the issue of whether there was administrative incompetence, at whatever level, and that both the Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department did not act several years ago on bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It pains me that that is a possibility and that this wretched legislation is the alternative that we face.

It has further been an unsavoury debate by the way the whole matter of tax evasion has been treated in Parliament in recent weeks. Make no mistake about it , the Australian Labor Party has blood in its nostrils on this subject. I listened to the debate in the House of Representatives. Lively as the debate was , many of the things said were absolutely unworthy of the honourable members who said them. The ALP has been at pains to paint the Fraser Government as a government which condones tax evasion. I have already said that I do not think that claim can be justified on any grounds. I think the Fraser Government has tried very hard to stop tax evasion in certain areas. However, I think that either the Government or its administrators-its servants-fell down on the job in relation to this type of tax evasion. We have all been reading for several years in the newspapers about bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and what was happening with them. I can recall reading about them in detail for at least two years in certain newspapers. I must say the reason they stuck in my mind at first was that it was a puzzlement as to how on earth people could get away with them. I spent some time two or three years ago, when the existence of these schemes was being alleged in newspapers, trying to sort out how they could possibly work and how people could avoid the arm of the law. However, they did work and this is the solution we are offered.

In recent weeks in debates in the Senate and in the other place the Labor Party has been beside itself with glee over certain revelations in relation to taxation avoidance. It has not attempted to treat the issue of tax evasion as anything other than an embarrassment to the Government, particularly in the light of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. That has not been a constructive debate; it has been a destructive one.
