It is my impression that many members of the Australian community are fed up to the teeth with the character assassination and the misuse of this chamber that has been part of the tax debate. It seems that I am not the only person prepared to put this view on record. I will quote from the 'Bishop's Newsletter' of 21 October 1982 of the Bishop of Canberra and Goulburn. The bishop gave his view on the whole tax evasion debate and retrospective taxation. I think it is a view worth putting into the record and taking some note of because the bishop who could not be claimed to be in favour of tax evasion, to be covering up for tax dodgers, or to have anything himself to hide or gain from the issue. He said:

The tax evasion issue grinds on. If it has done nothing else, it has forced us to think a bit about moral issues in public life, and that is certainly to the good. However, like everything to do with money, when people dwell on it too much, this debate is destroying trust between human beings, and is exposing, once again, the fragility of our political life.

Of course, tax evasion is highly undesirable. In that it is an act against others for the sake of one's own personal gain it is immoral and to be deplored. Moreover, the 'bottom of the harbour' mode is the more unsavoury because it seems to have been mainly practised by people who are financially relatively secure. 'How hard it is for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God,' said Jesus, and this whole issue seems to illuminate the saying.

Yet, I wonder if retrospective legislation is the way ahead. There is, to begin with, the problem of the precedent that it establishes. Is it the size of the sum lost to the state (whatever that amounts to) which leads the government to depart from established convention? If so, is it a good enough reason, and can we be sure that the motives for enacting retrospective legislation next time will be irreproachable?

Given the protections of the law and the ballot box, the problem of precedent need not be taken too seriously. Of greater concern is the kind of witch-hunt to which it could lead. How much will we be bettered as a nation by the allegations , investigations and prosecutions that the legislation will authorise? How shall we manage to wait from night to night for the next enthralling episode in the TV coverage of the whole wretched business? I would be far happier if recent experience had led to some imaginative, far-ranging new legislation to deal with present and future tax evasion, with tough penalties, than to further damage the nation by trying to recover lost millions from the past.

Of course, it galls me if I stop to think about it that people who could well have afforded to pay escape scot-free while I had to pay up, but that is hardly the point. The only course worth following now is to do that which will harm us all least.

There is, you see, another strand in all this. It is that sins against society are as old as society itself. The only difference these days is the scale of them. In the past, as well as public obloquy when things were found out, there was the accepted spiritual machinery for repentance and absolution. Most of the time these days, the nation itself has somehow to absorb the hurts inflicted upon it, because the spiritual processes are ignored. One must wonder about society's level of tolerance: whether it can possibly withstand the tensions and pressures that retrospective legislation may well impose. Acceptance of what has been done may be much less of a burden than retribution and the quest of compensation. There is even the possibility of some national and spiritual growth in that: how good it would be if we could seize it.

I reiterate the bishop's words: 'How much will we be bettered as a nation by the allegations, investigations and prosecutions that the legislation will authorise ?' One can almost imagine the salivating on the part of some people, once this legislation is passed, at the individual retribution and character assassinations which will take place.

I reiterate that I do not condone those who seek to avoid their moral obligations as citizens to pay tax. It must be said, of course, that those who have avoided tax in this manner are not the only ones to do so. Most people who have involved themselves with such vigour in this debate have shown a total reluctance to address themselves, for example, to the cash economy. Senator Gietzelt, when he spoke in the Senate last week, made a case about the proportion of total tax collections increasing for pay-as-you-earn taxpayers and decreasing in the company area. These are statements of facts and nobody disputes them. But one cannot claim that all the increase in the PAYE area is because of a decrease in the company area. At the moment the cash economy is rife. Some people will work only for cash; some will work overtime only for cash ; some will work at weekends only for cash. Those people are costing us all money. Those who, through their business arrangements, have minimised their tax are not the only ones to cost the PAYE person money; those who avoid paying the tax that they should pay, in whatever form, do so also.

The Australian Labor Party has said that this legislation does not go far enough. It proclaims that retrospective legislation is its policy. I ask the Australian Labor Party to make clear to the people of Australia in the context of this debate whether, should it come to government, it will legislate retrospectively in relation to the cash economy. I also ask it to make clear whether it will legislate retrospectively in relation to capital gains. It is very clear to the nation that the Labor Party intends to extend the present capital gains provision in our taxation legislation. It has made that attitude clear for some time. If, by some mishap, the Labor Party were to come to power at some time in the future, to what point would it make capital gains tax retrospective? Would it be the time that it clearly defined its policy, the time when it alleges this became a major form of tax evasion, or the time it actually enacted the legislation? The Labor Party needs to make itself much clearer on this issue. If it did, the whole potential for the retrospective taxation muddle that will follow would become clearer to everyone.

While people inside Parliament and outside are venting their indignation and expressing moral outrage at people who have avoided tax, as is covered in this legislation, it might be good for them to focus for some time on the full ramifications of this retrospective legislation. No matter how inadequate the law at a given time, I believe citizens have to know that the law they are acting under today is the law they will be prosecuted under tomorrow if their actions today are unacceptable tomorrow. If through tax investigation or any other form of investigation people's activities are called into question they have to know that if the action was committed at a time when it was legal it continues to be legal until it is declared illegal and the illegality dates only from the date of that change of heart.

There are risks in this legislation. People have the right to know that they act under the certainty of the law as it exists at the time. There are risks in this legislation that innocent people will suffer. It is not good enough for honourable senators opposite and some honourable senators on this side of the chamber to sweep that aside and say that there were no innocent people. Those same newspapers which have thundered in their editorials about the retrospective taxation legislation and claim that those who oppose it are supporting tax evasion-that is quite an erroneous allegation-will be the ones who when this legislation comes into effect will be thundering about the injustices that are done to the innocents under this legislation. They will be thundering at the Government and at the Australian Taxation Office about how surviving spouses, most likely widows, and how children, offspring, of those who have died in the last 10 years who minimised their tax in this wayl have assets taken from them because of actions that they did not commit and things over which they had no control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Assets which they should not have had in the first place.
—Some people do not like the fact that anybody has any assets. Some people, if they were held up by their heels and were shaken, as in the colourful language of Mr Hinze--
—Doesn't an age pensioner have to pay back part of the age pension if he or she is overpaid?

—Some senators are also greedy, are they not? They have made their speech but they want time that is allocated to somebody else's speech too. As I was saying, some people would not have two bob if they were shaken. Some people, by dint of their own exertion, hard work, talents, abilities, entrepreneurial activities and whatever, do have assets. There are people in the community who resent anybody having assets, resent anybody having a high income even if they are paying their full share of tax. These are people who shout and scream now, who blackguard others, who use their opportunities in this chamber to blacken the names of others, who degrade this debate into nothing more than character assassination.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of retrospective tax is a serious and fundamental one about the status of our own laws, about how we in this law-making body regard the status of the laws that exist today. I will vote against the legislation. I will do so with a heavy heart. I am aware that the Government claims that this is part of its Budget legislation, but I find it totally repugnant and totally unacceptable . The innocence clause proposal which would exempt those people who did act in good faith and in innocence, without awareness of what would be the final consequences of what these bottom-of-the-harbour operators were up to, is one that I would seek to support.

When the second reading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill comes to a vote and the innocence clause proposal is debated in Committee I may not be present in the chamber. Months ago I obtained a pair for tomorrow and I have a commitment in my electorate. It appears that we may vote tomorrow, in which case I may well be absent from the chamber and unable to indicate in the Senate record that I am opposed to this legislation, that I am prepared to vote against it, that I think, at the very least, there ought to be protection in it for innocence and that, therefore I would be prepared to vote for the innocence clause when moved in Committee. It is possible that I shall be here to vote, however it now appears unlikely. I therefore place my views on the Senate record .
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania on the demand and supply of electricity in Tasmania and other matters, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
The Select Committee on South West Tasmania was appointed by the Senate on 23 September 1981 to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the natural values of South West Tasmania to Australia and the World; and

(b) Federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance consistent with the State's development needs and options for the State's energy requirements.

The inquiry was advertised widely in the national Press in November 1981 and attracted 746 written submissions of which 606 were received from the mainland States and Territories and 140 from Tasmania. Early in the inquiry, the Committee decided that it should first consider demand for electricity in Tasmania and the supply options available for meeting that demand. The Committee would then examine the environmental impacts of the feasible options and the effects of other types of land use, such as mining, forestry, tourism and recreation, on South West Tasmania.

The Committee also initially decided to confine its first report to demand and supply of electricity for Tasmania and to report on the environmental, land use and Commonwealth assistance matters in a second report. The Committee therefore concentrated on demand and supply matters in the public hearings held on 17 days since 4 February 1982. However, two more topics were subsequently considered and are therefore now additionally included in this report. These were the significance of the archaeological discoveries near the Franklin river and the powers and obligations of the Commonwealth as a signatory to the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention on World Heritage in relation to South West Tasmania.

The Committee has not completed examining all the matters contained in its terms of reference, but it has reached certain conclusions on the matters examined. The Committee had available to it several studies on the demand for power in Tasmania, based on different methodologies and containing a wide divergence of demand projections. The Committee's consultants, McLachlan Group Pty Ltd, prepared a forecast of demand which took account of the possibility of either high or low growth in demand. For the purposes of the Committee's conclusions the Committee adopted the McLachlan Group forecast of demand. The forecast contained a demand projection within a band which widened the further into the future it went. McLachlan Group stated that there was, as well, a probability of one in four that demand would still fall outside that forecast band.

The demand projections of the Hydro-Electric Commission fell just outside the upper limit of the McLachlan Group forecast band in 1990 and 1995 but were well within the band in 2000. The HEC's lower limit fell within the band in all three years. If the lower limit of the McLachlan Group's forecast band were achieved little or no additional capacity would be needed to the end of this century. It is likely that demand will actually be somewhere within the two extremes but, even if a high growth in demand eventuates, a major new generating facility would not need to be operational until the mid-1990s. The Committee therefore concludes that construction of a major option-that is, the Gordon-below-Franklin scheme, a thermal station or interconnection with Victoria-does not have to be commenced for at least three years, while still allowing the upper limit of the forecast of demand to be met.

Irrespective of the length of the current recession the future economic outlook for Australia is uncertain. There may be booms, further recessions or both. A supply strategy needs to take account of this uncertainty as well as the risks attached to any development program. There is generally risk attached to the outlay of large sums of capital on major public works projects. Capital is a scarce commodity and competition for capital is increasing. It is not in the public interest if a large capital investment is not fully productive because the project is underutilised. It is therefore in the public interest to minimise the risk attached to any public project.

In a period of uncertainty, the risks attached to public development projects increase. Investment decisions should therefore be directed towards flexibility to minimise those risks. This can be achieved by small increments, short construction lead times and relatively small capital outlays. Sometimes the forgoing of economies of scale in maintaining flexibility may be more desirable than running the risk of having public moneys tied up in unproductive generating capacity. The Committee decided that a supply strategy which would respond quickly to exigencies but ensure continuity of supply while minimising the risk of having substantial capital tied up in unused generating facilities is required.
To commence construction of a major option at this time would be inconsistent with that strategy, and therefore the Committee proposed the following supply program:

1. The construction of one or more small hydro-electric schemes which, apart from providing insurance against a shortfall in supply by a sudden and unexpected increase in demand, would alleviate some of the unemployment problems within the HEC if the Gordon-below-Franklin scheme were abandoned.
2. The planning of several different minor options which then, if required, could be commenced quickly.
3. Further investigation into the feasibility of thermal power and the detailed evaluation of Tasmanian coal reserves.

4. Further investigation into the feasibility of interconnection with Victoria with regard to the provision of power for Tasmania, the exchange of power between Tasmania and Victoria on an opportunity basis and the sharing of reserve capacity.
5. Active research and development of magneto hydro dynamics, photovoltaic cells, aerogenerators and other forms of potential electricity generation.
6. The implementation of a comprehensive energy management program.
7. The systematic monitoring of demand.

Although this report deals mainly with demand for power in Tasmania and a supply strategy to meet that demand, the Committee decided to include in its consideration two additional topics which emerged during the course of the inquiry-the significance of the archaeological discoveries near the Franklin River and the Commonwealth's obligations and powers in relation to South West Tasmania. On the basis of expert evidence received, the Committee concluded that the archaeological discoveries near the Franklin River are of such international importance that they should not be inundated.

Although the Committee did not receive independent legal opinion on the question of the Commonwealth's powers and obligations in relation to South West Tasmania, it did receive a number of relevant submissions. It also had available to it an opinion prepared by Mr D. J. Rose of the Attorney-General's Department which was incorporated in the House of Representatives Hansard on 19 October 1982. On the evidence before it, the Committee believes that certain conclusions can reasonably be drawn and no contrary evidence has been taken by the Committee . The Commonwealth may well be obliged to act to preserve the area and has a considerable number of powers and options open to it to enable it to meet that responsibility.

The nomination of the Western Tasmanian Wilderness National Parks for listing on the World Heritage List was not central to the areas of this part of the inquiry or the evidence the Committee primarily called. However, the Committee has stated in its report that nothing has emerged from the inquiry which should persuade the Commonwealth Government from proceeding with the listing which involves the Government in fulfilling its obligations and responsibilities under the provisions of the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.

There is also a minority report of which I am the author and in which I express major disagreements. However, in the interest of assisting in the maintenance of the sessional orders I am prepared to wait until Thursday to conclude my remarks . Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 and associated legislation. I have no intention of delaying the passage of this legislation. However, there have been many speakers, from both sides of the House-a large number on the opposite side of the House are in fact opposing the legislation-and we feel it is important to reiterate our position. After years of presiding over what has been an unprecedented erosion of the tax base and an erosion of public and private morality in tax matters, the Government finally has decided to get back a part, a very small part, of what it and the community, and in particular pay-as-you- earn taxpayers have lost. It has done this only after public pressure has forced it, I suggest reluctantly, into action.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980, the Government proudly introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act which made participation in bottom-of-the-harbour or straw company schemes a criminal offence. However, those who got in before this legislation was passed were able to escape scot-free. But then we had the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union exposing the true extent of such schemes and, I believe, the true extent of the culpability of the Government and, in some cases , public servants in letting this appalling situation develop. The Australian Taxation Office was aware of the schemes as early as 1973. In late 1975 it was proposed, after much advice, that a test case be mounted. Unfortunately, those who were chosen to conduct that case, largely in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, although the responsibility cannot just rest there, appear to have been strangely reluctant to prosecute. Other more important matters, it seems, were occupying their minds at the time. So, while the government and bureaucratic wheels ground on, tax avoidance and evasion schemes flourished in this country. They florished to such an extent that an eminent authority on taxation, Professor Russell Mathews, estimated that they cost in total as much as $7,000m per annum. Estimates vary at all sorts of levels but, whatever the estimates, they are considerable. It is the ordinary taxpayers, those caught in the pay-as-you-earn dragnet, and those honest taxpayers who pay their tax bill as necessary who have had to pay through the nose for this toleration of tax avoidance and tax evasion.

The unfortunate thing, I believe, is that no one in high office is to be held responsible for this breathtaking neglect and incompetence. The Solicitor- General is not to be held to account for the inaction of this office. The Treasurer (Mr Howard), it would seem, hears no evil and sees no evil. Yet it is clear from the telephone book of documents which were tabled in the Senate that the Commissioner of Taxation, amongst others, repeatedly stressed the urgent need for action in this area. Now, belatedly, some of the staggering revenue losses resulting from these schemes, particularly the straw company scheme, are to be recouped. But the legislation is such that the recoupment will be too little and too late. This scheme is only the most remarkable of an evasion and avoidance iceberg which penetrates deeply into Australian society.

The Australian Labor Party does not oppose the legislation. Indeed, the principle of retrospective tax legislation is one which we have advocated-we do not resile from it-as the only way effectively to curb such avoidance practices in this country. But there are deficiencies in the legislation which are of concern to the Labor Party and which have been detailed, particularly by Senator Walsh and Senator Evans, in this debate. Firstly, the legislation will recoup only evaded company income tax and undistributed profit tax. No attempt has been made to collect the individual income tax which would otherwise have been paid on dividends distributed to shareholders. It is suggested that this could easily involve a total tax liability of half as much again as the $580m which the Treasurer, some would say rather optimistically, hopes to recoup through this legislation. Secondly, there is no attempt to charge interest over the period between the time tax was originally evaded and the time assessments are served on shareholders and promoters. For some schemes this could go back as far as January 1972-some 10 years. In effect, the Government has made a substantial interest free loan to those who participated in such schemes, albeit indirectly. This, I suggest, can scarcely be a disincentive to further such endeavours.

Taking account of inflation, the schemes will have cost the revenue much more than the $580m which is sought to be recouped-some suggest as much as $1,000m in current year dollars. Even the conditions for payment after these assessments have been made have been watered down in the amended legislation. Certainly, a 20 per cent penalty tax will commence to accrue if tax is not paid within 30 days of the initial assessment, but should the shareholder decide not to contest the assessment he or she, on paying 25 per cent deposit, will be able to pay the residue in instalments over a 12-month period. This scheme provides far more generous conditions than the payment conditions that are available to ordinary taxpayers in this community.

Finally, there is the remarkable late amendment in the legislation designed, apparently, to mollify those who seek an innocence clause; that is, where companies were put into a tax avoidance scheme with a 'reasonable expectation' that that scheme would be successful and only afterwards were sent to the bottom of the harbour, the company, vendors and promoters involved are exempted from the legislation even if the avoidance scheme failed. This provision, it is said, will affect some 700 of the 4,500 companies so far identified by the Taxation Office as being affected by the recoupment legislation. In fact, the Government is saying that if the Taxation Office succeeds before the courts in striking down schemes such as those of the Curran type a tax obligation will apply. But if a company has gone to the bottom of the harbour the Government will not bother to collect tax from the shareholders or promoters who benefited from the scheme. This would seem to be an anomalous situation and one which appears to protect a particular category of tax dodgers-those who made what one could call 'a legitimate pretence at dodging tax'. Such a distinction between classes of tax dodgers is a typical example of the sort of hair-splitting that we have heard on this issue. I think I should remind honourable senators again that, in May 1981, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:
There is no real difference between a person who finds an artificial loophole to slip out of tax and a person who falsely declares his income.

Yet, this legislation, I suggest, attempts to do precisely that. It leaves the accumulated profits strip schemes, the so-called dry Slutzkins, alone. It neglects the avoided individual income tax on accumulated profits that should have arisen under the wet Slutzkins or bottom-of-the-harbour schemes when those profits were distributed as dividends. It excludes those schemes where some legitimate attempt at tax avoidance was made. The overall result is a much watered-down piece of legislation. Only a fraction of the moneys which have dissipated through these schemes will ever be collected. Some of the rich hustlers will continue to wax fat. The tragedy is that the ordinary workers and PAYE taxpayers in the community will, in fact, continue to bear the burden.

I think it is an interesting reflection on the priorities of this Parliament, on the media and, indeed, on large sections of our community that, in this debate, there are 22 speakers, most of them from the Government side. There have been endless words in the Press and a very expensive campaign has been waged in all the advertising media in this country against the legislation and against attempts to recoup, under these circumstances, tax which should have legitimately been paid. This legislation has been watered down to the extent of the hair-splitting between what is considered evasion and what is considered avoidance. This has been the final outcome of this legislation. I suggest that if only such interest and effort were aimed at overcoming the problems of poverty and the disadvantaged, and at debating such problems, the country would be a lot better off. But the tragedy is that the people at whom this legislation is directed are a small group of the many who, by their artificial and illegal attacks on the revenue, not only make things worse for the PAYE taxpayers and other honest taxpayers, who include some of the low income people, but also make it difficult for governments of any persuasion to get sufficient revenue to redress some of the inequities in our society if they seek to do so.

I know that some, but not all, of those who oppose the legislation do so for proper motives. Senator Hill, for instance, in a thoughtful speech, came to the conclusion that he should oppose the legislation because he believed, when weighing up the pros and cons, that the application of retrospectivity was wrong , certainly in this case, and, secondly, that legislation was not necessary in light of the Crimes Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act, and the powers already available in other legislation. Senator Hill, unlike some other honourable senators, did not make the extraordinary statement that the Liberal Party was against all retrospective taxation as a matter of principle and therefore that that was grounds on which he was opposing the legislation. I am glad that he did not do so, because I think that those who make that sort of remark should go to the Age of 22 November, yesterday, which reports that the Leader of the Liberal Party in the Victorian Upper House, Mr Hunt, in a debate on this sort of general principle, said that in 21 years in Parliament he-
had supported more than 150 pieces of retrospective legislation with a clear conscience.
He is quoted as saying:
If anyone tells me that is not Liberal, or contrary to principle, I say that we don't belong to the same party. It's nonsense to create an overall principle where none exists.

I concede that Senator Hill did not fall into that trap, but we have heard that from other speakers on the Government side who oppose this legislation. But most in this Parliament clearly do not agree with Senator Hill, Senator Martin and others who came to the decision that the retrospective aspects of this legislation were, on balance, wrong. I believe that most of us do not do so because the legislation is what it says it is-recoupment legislation. It aims at recouping tax evaded through patently artificial schemes. We believe that it should aim at recouping tax avoided through patently artificial avoidance schemes. It imposes no penalty in the true sense of that word but provides for recoupment of what, in any sense of the term, should fairly have been paid. It gives time to repay and it provides a let-out clause for a large group of people who clearly, in the Opposition's view, should not have been let out but who clearly the Government, under pressure, has decided to let out.

Those of us who deal with social security matters know that pensioners and beneficiaries who are overpaid, either through innocent misunderstanding of the regulations on their part or through mistakes by the Department, have those overpayments recouped under the legislation as it exists now. There is and has been no hue and cry on their behalf by those who oppose this legislation. There is no expensive, organised campaign. But the the situation is analogous and I think that it should be brought up, as Senator Walsh and others have brought it up in this debate. Certainly there are under existing legislation, provisions to take action against some of these tax evaders. Certainly there was as Senator Hill pointed out opportunity for the Government to take legislative action before this.

If such action had been taken, we know that it would have had a salutary effect on the burgeoning tax avoidance and evasion industry. We know that action was to be taken in the courts in 1975 but was not proceeded with as a result of the extraordinary behaviour in the Crown Solicitor's Office. Mr Costigan makes that clear. As I have said, we know from the documents produced in this place that the Commissioner of Taxation, with an increasing sense of urgency, urged that action be taken. That it was not taken is a reflection not only on the Crown Solicitor's Office but also on the Treasurer. Nowhere are there more condemnatory words about what happened in that situation than those of the Treasurer, when he stated that among the reasons action was not taken earlier was that there was insufficient public concern and expression of it. The role of government when that sort of thing is brought to its attention is to act, and act promptly.

But the practicalities of the matter are that to proceed under available legislation would be uncertain, tortuous, enormously expensive and time- consuming, and would not necessarily result in justice and equity now that the gate has been left open for so long, now that the companies have been reduced to shells, now that some of them have disappeared beneath the waters. What this debate is about, as those who have supported the legislation have repeatedly said, is justice and equity for the vast majority of the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers and other honest taxpayers. As far as the Labor Party is concerned, this legislation does not go far enough towards achieving that. Hence our second reading amendment and our later amendments at the committee stage.

If, in fact, we are to have some sense of equity and justice in the taxation system in this country and some morality in the distribution of the wealth of this community, unfortunately, because of past actions by many people, this legislation has become necessary. It is for that reason that the Australian Labor Party and I support the legislation to the extent that we do. We are disappointed that it does not go further. We will try to amend it to make it go further but at least it is a step in the right direction, a small step though that may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is slowly wending its weary way towards its predestined conclusion. I do not want to add any great amount to the flood of words which has already been spoken and which will be spoken on this subject. I am speaking for two reasons. Firstly, I make clear that a large majority of Government senators support the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 and associated measures. Secondly, I want to put a few simple propositions to the Senate. The first is that this Parliament clearly has the power, if it so chooses, to legislate retrospectively. There can be no doubt about that. We have the power and we have used it repeatedly. We have used it for instance, many times without protest, with regard to benefits. The fact that there was no protest there was very reasonable. We used our powers very often with regard to retrospective taxation legislation. Every time we change company tax the legislation is, in fact, retrospective. A change in company tax applies to the previous year's profits. There is no outcry about that. It is accepted, but that is and we must understand that it is retrospective tax legislation. This Parliament has also legislated retrospectively with regard to criminal acts . In 1915 an amendment was made to the Crimes Act with retrospective effect. I very much doubt whether any retrospective Act on criminal matters would pass this Parliament now. I certainly very much doubt that I would support such a decision. Nevertheless, if Parliament so chooses, in appropriate circumstances, it does have the power to act retrospectively. In other areas-not criminal matters-this Parliament should pass legislation which is retrospective only when a very clear need has been made out. In this case I think the need has been made out. One of the most important principles we must consider as a Parliament is the principle of fairness in taxation, fairness in administration and fairness in legislation. Mr Justice Isaacs, many years ago, summed up this problem for us very clearly. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What may seem unjust when regarded from the standpoint of one person affected may be absolutely just when a broad view is taken of all who are affected. There is no remedial Act which does not affect some vested right, but, when contemplated in its total effect, justice may be overwhelmingly on the other side.

In this case there has been much talk of the innocent when, in my view, the innocent in this situation have been those taxpayers-principally pay-as-you-earn taxpayers-who have been paying their income tax, perhaps reluctantly, but honestly. The guilty-I am not talking in legal terms-are those who have been paying no tax at all through artificial avoidance schemes. The innocent in this situation are the people who have been genuinely and honestly paying their tax.

There have been various suggestions that perhaps we should have dealt with other types of artificial avoidance schemes but the key element in this one is that there was fraud somewhere in the chain. This fraud, this stripping of companies of their assets so they are unable to pay their debt to the Commissioner of Taxation, has always been illegal. The 1980 Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act did not really create a new offence. It only made that offence easier to prosecute. What it was dealing with was always illegal and always fraudalent. Let there be no confusion at all about that.

Senator Chipp asked the question and I think it must be answered: Why do we not prosecute these people under the existing law, the law in particular that existed prior to 1980? There are two problems about this. The first is that the prosecutions before 1980-for acts committed before 1980-would have to be for conspiracy, either under the Crimes Act, or perhaps under the Companies Act. In either case the prosecutions would be expensive, complex and uncertain. We have seen recent cases of prosecutions under the Crimes Act involving millions of dollars and no convictions. To embark on that course would be a very expensive and probably wasteful exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, would you concede that if that had been done in 1976 it may have avoided this?

—If it had been successful then it would have. I do not want to get on to the area, which I must concede is one of very great sensitivity for us as a government, as to why we did not take action in 1976. I think we should have. In the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union we heard the various reasons why we did not do so, but I am trying to deal with what the situation is now. The prosecutions were not launched in 1975 or 1976. I wish that they had been but to launch them now, using the Crimes Act would be a very cumbersome and difficult exercise, the main beneficiaries of which would be the lawyers. Even if we did prosecute-we would be prosecuting the promoters, by the way-we would not get our money back because the main beneficiaries, the people who have the money, have not committed a fraudulent act. They are the shareholders. Even if we were to pursue this course we still would not get back the very large amount of money of which the community has been defrauded. For those reasons these Bills are necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case we are going after the vendor-shareholders; the people who got the money. All they are being asked to do in this legislation is to give back money that they should never have had. We are, very properly, by an amendment introduced after the legislation was originally drafted, also going after the promoters to make them repay a fair share of the amount of which the community has been defrauded. In this legislation there is no question of guilt or innocence. No one is being convicted of anything. There are no penalties. If the vendor-shareholders pay up there will be no publicity although I see a proposed amendment which suggests that their names should be publicised. I do not think that this is appropriate. If the vendors pay back to the community the amounts that they should never have had that will be the end of the matter; if they like to fight it, of course, there will be publicity.

Morally these vendor-shareholders are like people who buy an expensive watch for $10 in a pub. Perhaps they get an argument that it is a good buy. Perhaps they get someone to examine it and tell them that it is an excellent deal or deliberately, perhaps, they ask no questions at all. Whichever course of action they take it does not give them the title to that watch against the true owner. In this case the true owner of this money is the community. Morally and, now under this legislation, legally they will have to pay the money back.

There is one further advantage that has not been mentioned very much in this debate but I think it is an important one. We are dealing with a very difficult area of public morality where there has been a gross degradation in recent years of the willingness of people to pay their taxes. I am sure that many of us have sat around a table, sometimes in silent outrage and sometimes in noisy rebuke of rich people who say that paying tax is optional. This is an outrageous statement for them to make but it has been made many times in recent years. There has been a substantial and very important change in community attitudes to tax avoidance. I think it is good. But what this legislation does is serve as a warning to people not to get involved in questionable schemes in the future. Therefore I hope that this legislation will not only deal with the past schemes-the bottom- of-the-harbour schemes-but also make it much less likely that people will in the future get involved in such questionable schemes. Therefore, I support this legislation and will vote against all amendments to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Hamer just said, a flood of words has emanated during this debate on these taxation Bills. I just want to make it quite clear at the outset that I will not, nor will I ever, support what I term and what I understand is a retrospective law. As I understand it, and I have listened to numbers of speakers in this debate, it appears that a law existed but some people either avoided their responsibility to pay tax or went through a phase of evading tax. Those people should have been dealt with under that law. If there was not such a law and if they did not break a law at the time, I do not believe that now, 10 years later, we can introduce a law which will be retrospective to 10 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to make it quite clear that I have no truck whatsoever with people who break the law. I have no truck with people who will not accept their responsibilities to this country, to this nation as a whole, and make their contributions as most other people have to do. Of course, there are people who do not have the opportunity to minimise their tax in any fraudulent way because they, like myself-I have done so all my life-have to pay taxes as they earn their income. I have no escape route, as some of these people had, to avoid paying tax and living up to my responsibilities.

I believe that it was wrong for them to do what they did. If such a law was in existence at that time, they should have been taken before the courts and made to pay their fair share of taxes. If that law still exists, I believe we should be using it. If no such law existed and those people did not break the law at that time, I believe that they still should have paid their taxes. They did something that was immoral. Okay; so let us introduce a law effective from now to ensure that those people can never again evade taxes as they did in the past. But if there was a law in existence, that law should be used to bring them to justice.

I do not believe that I have a right to support legislation that deals with people's moral codes. If people want to act immorally, I will not introduce legislation to say that they should not act immorally. That is entirely up to them and their consciences. If they want to do something that they know is immoral, and they persist in doing it, it is on their consciences-not mine. I am here as a legislator, as a law-maker, but a law-maker in the sense that the law must be made now and acted upon from now-not made retrospective to 10 years ago.

As I understand it, the period from 1972, the date to which this law is to be made retrospective, to the present covers the terms of three governments which would have had knowledge that this type of thing was happening. In fact, it covers the terms of more than three governments; it covers the terms of the McMahon Government, two Whitlam governments and three or four Fraser governments . There was knowledge that this was going on but it appears that none of those governments did anything about it. Now the Government has decided to do something about it. The way it is going about it is to make legislation retrospective to 1972. I have no intention of supporting that. I certainly will vote for the innocence clause proposal. If that is defeated, I certainly will not vote for this retrospective law dealing with bottom-of-the-harbour schemes or whatever one likes to call them. I will have no part of it. I want to make my position clear. I will not support it. I have talked to many people, not only in my State but also in other States. I have talked to people from all walks of life. Very few people indeed have told me that they would support this kind of legislation. Therefore, I say again that I do not support this legislation. I certainly will be voting against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation provides for the payment into the Commonwealth public revenues of moneys equivalent to unpaid company tax assessed and payable but which is unrecoverable from the company concerned due to that company being stripped of its assets and most of its records being dumped, in many instances literally, in the bottom of Sydney Harbour. I support this legislation though not without considerable misgivings and some questioning which I have tried to settle before coming to that decision. I support the legislation as it has emerged in this chamber but subject, of course, to the reservations expressed in the amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Peter Walsh. Before commencing my own contribution to the debate may I say that I feel that the way in which the Senate has conducted its consideration of these Bills is a tribute to the Senate. Many contributions have been made covering the full gamut of opinion. They have all been very well thought out and all of them, in my view, have been genuine and sincere.

SPEECH.PARA: I do support this package of Bills which seek, as I understand it, to recoup tax which is legally payable. There is a legal liability to company tax which is assessed and due but that liability cannot be attached to any individual person at the moment without the aid of this legislation. To that extent it is true to say that this legislation is retrospective. It genuinely attaches a liability to pay moneys to persons who otherwise would not have expected to pay moneys to the Commonwealth public revenues, namely, the vendor-shareholders and promoters of the schemes involved. It is true that there is a liability to pay tax. It is undoubtedly true that, insofar as profits were earned during the year's activities, in relation to that company's profits, there is always an expected, a certain, attaching of legal consequences to the activity of earning those company profits. The law is quite definite and certain. Forty-six dollars out of every $100 of current year profits were payable to the Federal revenue. It is not as though we are creating a new legal liability in the sense of unexpectedly attaching tax consequences at the rate of $46 in the $100 to the activity of earning company profits.

What is new and what is retrospective is that this legislation decides to attach liability to pay that company tax to those who benefited from certain arrangements which made it impossible to recover the tax from the company concerned. This law attaches liability to the vendor-shareholders and to the promoters. The question that faces us is whether that attaching of liability to those vendor-shareholders and promoters is intolerable and unjust in a society which generally seeks to achieve its social ends involving government by the raising of revenue through tax laws which are fair and certain. I may say in passing that certainty is an argument that cuts both ways. The taxpayer is entitled to certainty. Certainly the Government in those years from 1972 to 1980 , until the passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, was entitled to certainty in arranging its affairs on the basis of an expected revenue from company profits. It could have been expected from a gauge being made of economic activity and business enterprise activity within the economy that certain moneys would flow to the Federal Treasury in order to discharge the matters for which government is responsible such as defence, social security, health and so on.

Reasonable projections on the scale of corporate activity and its profitability are made year by year by the Federal Government and it sets its tax scales accordingly. The activities of the promoters of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes meant that those programs were placed in jeopardy, that many pay-as-you-earn taxpayers had to pay higher rates than they would otherwise have done, that the deficit at times was larger than anticipated and, therefore, borrowings of Government, with all their impact on interest rates and so on, had to be undertaken. All this was because the certainty of payment of company tax legally due was frustrated and hindered by those who sought advantage in these schemes. For those people to speak of certainty invites the rejoinder that there is also an entitlement in government to certainty in relation to its raising of revenue. The community has a right to certainty in its revenue also. Insofar as this legislation seeks to ensure that the due moneys flow to Treasury, though belatedly, then I suppose that it could be said that it helps to fulfil that early predicability and certainty which, as I say, has been frustrated by these schemes. But that is only in passing. It remains true that neither the vendor- shareholders nor the promoters of these schemes would have expected to be made personally liable for the payment of this company tax. The question is: Is it fair that they should be made so liable?

I think it ought to be made very clear what the legislation does not do retrospectively. It does not impose a criminal penalty retrospectively-that is, it does not attach the stigma of criminal conviction to a person in respect of activities innocent of any criminality, say, three, five, or eight years ago. If , indeed, there were any criminal intent to defraud the revenue that would be a different matter and would be covered by the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, as many speakers have said. There would be a question of whether the promoters of these schemes had such an intent. Insofar as any vendor-shareholders were in collusion with a promoter, fully understanding the proposal to defraud the revenue, then the criminal character of the arrangements is determined then and there. Insofar as the vendor-shareholders were entirely innocent of any intent to defraud then nothing in this legislation that we are dealing with would attribute the mental elements of a crime. So, there is certainly nothing retrospective in the criminal sphere in this legislation.

There is an attachment of liability to pay the tax which ought to have been paid by the company. That is new and unexpected, whether one be a vendor- shareholder or promoter, and is, as I say, genuinely retrospective. To that extent, misgivings and certain caution are required. I believe that general common law tradition envisages that in specific instances this can be regarded as a fair impost on those concerned. I think, actually, the editorial writer in the Australian Financial Review of 17 August this year expressed my view when he said:

But non-retrospectivity of the tax law is by no stretch of the imagination an absolute moral or political value . . . . Clearly, retrospectivity is more a serious issue with respect to criminal law than with respect to income tax law.
As I have already said, this legislation is not retrospective criminal law; it is merely retrospective taxation law. The writer of the Australian Financial Review editorial went on to conclude:

In the case of the bottom of the harbour schemes the abuse of the tax system and the injustice is so gross that justice and fairness are on the side of retrospectivity. But the opponents of retrospectivity rightly warn of the dangers of taking it lightly. It should almost never be done.

I certainly do not take the retrospective aspect of this legislation lightly but I do find some reassurance in the words of Lord Greene. Lord Greene was the custodian of the common law tradition in England, being the Master of the Rolls in the 1940s. In 1941, in a Court of Appeal decision where Lord Greene spoke for himself and Lord Justices Clauson and du Parcq on a taxation case, he had this to say:
The fact that the section has to some extent a retroactive effect again appears to us-
This is the Court of Appeal in the United Kingdom and the Master of the Rolls, the custodian of the common law tradition, speaking-
of no importance when it is realised that the legislation is a move in a long and fiercely-contested battle with individuals who well understand the rigour of the contest.

Surely, that is the case in this particular contest going on between the legislature and those involved in taxation avoidance schemes. It is there recognised by the legal tradition to which we are the heirs that in the taxation area retroactive or retrospective legislation may be permitted. I find, contrary to the assertions of Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Hill in their otherwise excellent contributions to this debate, that in the United States, whilst it is true that there is a constitutional prohibition in Article 1, section 9, against expost facto laws, it is nevertheless also true that the Supreme Court has since 1798-that is, over 100 years before this Federation was formed-decided that that constitutional prohibition should be confined to laws imposing punishment, penal laws. In fact, the United States practice is to permit retroactive legislation in regard to tax matters.

In speaking of the United States practice-we are there speaking of the exemplar of a free economy where personal liberty from the exactions of government is highly prized-there is much greater discretion given to the taxation commissioner in respect of retroactive legislation than should ever be permitted in Australia. Thus, in section 7805 of the United States Internal Revenue Code it is provided:
The Secretary-
He is the equivalent of our Commissioner of Taxation-
may prescribe the extent, if any, to which any ruling or regulation, relating to the internal revenue laws, shall be applied without retroactive effect.

So, although it is couched in negative terms, that section gives the Secretary of the Treasury in the United States the power to decide the retrospective impact of any ruling or regulation in internal revenue matters. I am not for one moment suggesting that that fearsome, disruptive power ought to be given to a non-elected official, even one of the status of the Commissioner of Taxation. If there is to be retroactive legislation it ought to be by a clear, specific, case by case decision of the two chambers of this elected Parliament. Nevertheless, I point out that in both the United Kingdom and the United States there is recognised, by the legislatures and the courts, a place for retrospective legislation in the taxation area. I think that ought to settle some of the misgivings-certainly it helped to settle my misgivings-concerning the retrospective character of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You used the word 'penalty'. How do you define 'penalty' in this context?

—A penalty would be some additional criminal stigma being attached to the vendor-shareholder or the promoter by way of either a term of imprisonment or some actual fine which is additional to the moneys equivalent to company tax which have not flowed to the Treasury because of the scheme entered into. I would say that quite clearly the common law tradition and the United States constitutional prohibition would argue against such a penalty being imposed, but both traditions do permit retrospective tax legislation of the character before us. Nevertheless we, as Australian elected representatives, are called upon to decide whether the vendor-shareholders or the promoters of these schemes ought to pay into the Treasury moneys equivalent to the company tax evaded.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that they ought to is fairly clear because both parties have benefited and had available to them to dispose of or invest over a period moneys which could otherwise have been available for community purposes as determined by the Government. Therefore, I believe it is fair that they be required now to make those moneys available to the community. It is money of which they have had the use for no less than two years, accepting that the Crimes (Taxation Offences ) Act of 1980 has wiped out this practice. Maybe they have had the use of the money for up to five years or seven years. The community is seeking the money in numbers of dollars, which takes no account of the ravages of inflation, whereas the vendor-promoter may well have used the money as a hedge against inflation, particularly in investments where no capital gains tax applies. One can expect that the vendor-shareholder or promoter will have made some investment in a business or enterprise which has returned the money at least keeping up with inflation and no doubt doing somewhat better. The legislation further gives 12 months to pay. So the closure of business, sackings or liquidation of stock at unrealistically low prices will not be forced on those who have to pay. Perhaps in that regard some distinction ought to have been made in cases where immediate payment would cause genuine hardship. I am not going to quibble with the 12 months period of grace except to say that it rather upsets the Budget prediction as to how many hundreds of millions of dollars might be recouped in this financial year.

In relation to more general arguments that have been raised, I do not think the scale of avoidance is relevant at all to the question of whether it is fair to attach liability to the shareholders or the promoters. In that I am in entire agreement with those who have said that they will vote against this legislation. I do not think the scale of avoidance is at all relevant to the question of whether it is fair and correct to attach liability to the vendor-shareholders or the promoters. In my view it is enough to say of the shareholder or promoter that each actually, immediately, directly and quantifiably obtained a monetary advantage by virtue of the scheme in a way directly in proportion to the non- payment of company tax. The scale of avoidance explains the Government's belated action in this regard. What truth there is in the argument of those who oppose these Bills lies in the assertion that this is a political response to the public perception that the enormity of tax avoidance activity needs to be confronted.

The scale of that avoidance can be measured in two ways. It can be measured in terms of the hundreds of millions of dollars avoided. In 1981-82 I believe it was estimated that some $1,500m in tax was avoided. That money is made up by increased borrowings by the Government, with an impact on interest rates, by taxing the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, perhaps by some increased range or scale of indirect tax, or even by reduced government expenditure in some areas. That is one measurement. One can also refer to the sheer number of individuals involved in tax avoidance. The Commissioner of Taxation said that, in 1981-82, 58,366 individuals were identified as participating in these schemes. How many were not identified? That represents a thirty-threefold increase on the 1975-76 period-a mere six years ago.

None of that description justifies retrospective legislation. In that, the opponents of the Bills are correct. It justifies the most vigorous condemnation of a government whose procrastination in the administration and enforcement of its laws allowed the taxation avoidance industry to flourish. I refer to the documented failure to provide the Australian Taxation Office with the personnel- the sinews of war-to fight the battle. I refer also to the equally well- documented, pathetic incompetence of the Crown Solicitor's Office to mount a successful prosecution. The answer of the Government to that charge of incompetence should have been to accept ministerial responsibility for the abject failure of the departments of state which ought to have functioned effectively to protect the revenue. I do not include the Australian Taxation Office in those remarks. The Government cannot substitute this legislation for that proper political response. It boils down to this: Mr Costigan, at page 98 of his report, says:
The object of tax avoidance schemes is to avoid the payment of company tax on a company by leaving only a shell of the company with no assets to pay that tax.
These Bills seek to remedy that situation by looking to those who were immediately, directly and quantifiably advantaged by entering into those schemes . I think the Bills are fair in so doing.

The question any fair-minded person might ask is whether there could be such an individual as an innocent vendor-shareholder and, if so, whether an exception to the attachment of liability should be made in that case. I think it would be true in almost every instance to say that no vendor could receive $80,000 for a company with $100,000 worth of profits, on which in the normal course $46,000 would be payable by way of tax, without knowing or deliberately remaining ignorant about the probability that a tax avoidance scheme was involved to make the transaction commercially sensible, indeed viable, for the purchaser. That would have to be the case in most instances. If the vendor were only one of many very small shareholders in a company, then there may be some doubt whether that vendor would even suspect anything untoward as he received a few dollars for his few shares. When the assessment is for a sum less than $100 this legislation does not pursue that person. The very small, genuinely innocent shareholder is not pursued. Therefore, entire innocence seems to me to be most improbable.

But it may be said that the vendor, and indeed the promoter, could have been innocent in the sense that, knowing or suspecting that a tax avoidance scheme was afoot, they nevertheless assumed or were even advised that it was legal. It is not clear that the scheme was legal. Indeed, the advice of Mr Brinsden Q.C. and of many eminent counsel following him-and one suspects that there are opinions which the Government will not table in this place which would confirm the weight of legal opinion-is of the view that a criminal conspiracy to defraud was involved; that there could be civil recovery through the law of misfeasance. If that is the case, ignorance of the law, that is, of the law of conspiracy, or misfeasance in this case, is no excuse-whether such ignorance be self-induced or bought from professional advisers, lawyers or accountants.

It is evident, I agree, that until the Special Prosecutor mounts a case and a court decides in favour of the Government that there is a criminal conspiracy to defraud, this view remains unendorsed by the judiciary. But, as I say, it is undoubtedly the view of many eminent counsel, of Mr Costigan and of most opponents of this Bill, that it is unnecessary to do what ought to have been done by way of prosecution in the 1970s. Thus there is, in my view, no innocent vendor-shareholder of whose circumstances the common law requires recognition. As I say, ignorance of the law-that is, innocence as to the illegality involved in making the sale as profitable as it was in the face of apparent company tax liabilities-is no excuse. Insofar as some holders of a very small number of shares-who may have been quite unaware of any element of the situation-were affected, the Bill is not concerned to pursue them.

In the end I hope I have demonstrated why this Bill deserves support. I hope I have answered the genuine misgivings and questions which must arise in the mind of any fair-minded person. I hope, in short, that those honourable senators and members of the public who, like me, require the fullest justification for retrospective legislation, will come to the same point as I have in wishing this Bill passage through this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this package of Bills dealing with the recoupment of unpaid company tax, I think that honourable senators have two responsibilities. The first, I believe, is to deal with those in the community who have wilfully and fraudulently avoided paying tax and see that those taxes are recouped. The second is a responsibility to protect those people who are innocently involved in the matter we are discussing. The Fraser Government has done more to come to grips with tax avoidance than has any other Australian government. I can only totally agree and endorse this Government's efforts to recoup taxes that have been evaded by greedy and unscrupulous people who have created a situation whereby the rest of the community has to pay more personal taxation in order to cover the loss of revenue associated with tax avoidance. Tax avoiders are parasites on the Australian community and action to deal with such people must certainly be taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Since coming to office the Fraser Government has enacted a considerable number of pieces of legislation-about 30 I believe-designed to eradicate tax avoidance in many areas. Unlike the Opposition, with its new-found interest, this Government has acted over a number of years in this area. The Whitlam Government -as I have said before-laid great store on its concern about tax evasion and huffed and puffed quite a lot during the last part of its disastrous administration but did absolutely nothing. The particular form of avoidance with which we are dealing, the so-called bottom-of-the-harbour scheme, was first recognised by the Whitlam Government in 1973. This is clear from pages 27, 33 and 34 of the fourth interim report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Commissioner Costigan recounts how the schemes came to the attention of the Perth Office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor in 1973 and reports that an investigation was undertaken at that time.

This early detection of the schemes was also re-iterated in the response of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to the McCabe-Lafranchi report. In spite of detailed examination and on opinion by an eminent Q.C. from Western Australia, no prosecution was entered into at that time by the Attorneys-General Murphy or Enderby. The Australian community should not be fooled by the Australian Labor Party into believing that it alone is opposed to tax avoidance. The ALP's interest is new-found and does not match its record while in government. My concern about this legislation revolves around my belief that it is retrospective and the fact that innocent people will be caught up in the net envisaged by the package with which we are dealing at the moment. The retrospectivity of this measure is clearly spelt out in sub-clauses (1) and (2) of clause 5. Each of those sub-clauses in part states:
. . . a scheme entered into, whether in Australia or outside Australia, on or after 1 January 1972 and before 4 December 1980, some or all of the shares in a company were sold;

The legislation is clearly aimed at collecting taxes deemed due in the period between January 1972 and December 1980. The legislation will be retroactive in operation-that is, retrospectively applied. It makes laws so that those taxes can be recouped, but are those laws necessary? Mr Costigan and three Q.C.s who have provided advice to the Government over the last eight years do not think so . Since the schemes were first identified in 1973 no serious attempt has been made to collect those taxes under existing legislation. Given the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Companies Act and the Crimes Act the question must be posed as to why action has not been taken before against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

Commissioner Costigan, in his latest report, clearly identifies the legislation that could, and I believe should, have been used. Firstly, section 223 of the Income Tax Assessment Act makes it an offence not to submit a return and enables a fine to be imposed. Section 231 makes it an offence to avoid tax fraudulently and, again, a fine is incurred. Section 86 of the Crimes Act has been mentioned specifically before in this debate. That section provides that it is an offence to conspire with intent to defraud the Commonwealth. It also prescribes that it is an offence to make any attempt to defeat the operation of any Commonwealth law. The penalties provided for under this section are very severe and at least match those contained in the legislation before us at present. I remind the Senate that section 86(e) states:
A person who conspires with another person . . . to defraud the Commonwealth or a public authority under the Commonwealth, shall be guilty of an indictable offence.
It suggests a penalty of three years. I now turn to pages 31 and 32 of the Costigan report. Commissioner Costigan states:

I now turn to whether the scheme lent itself to criminal prosecution. It plainly does. Deliberately to denude a company of its assets so that it is unable to pay a debt is, and for a long time has been considered to be, a criminal fraud. If two or more men act together to achieve this purpose, then it is clear that they may be prosecuted at least pursuant to Section 86(e) of the Crimes Act, and probably at Common Law for cheating the Crown. If there is only one who does it without assistance, then he too may be prosecuted, though not for conspiracy but only for cheating the Crown. Should any of those men have played a part in the management of the company concerned, then they would also be liable for prosecution pursuant to the provisions of the Companies Acts.

I suggest that Costigan believes that they were liable to prosecution under those existing laws and so do three other Queen's Counsel whose opinions were sought by the Attorney-General's Department. In early 1975 Mr Brinsden, Q.C., now Justice Brinsden, firmly advised the Perth office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor that a promoter and others involved in a specific bottom-of-the- harbour scheme could be prosecuted under the Crimes Act. In July 1978 Mr Traill, Q.C. gave similar advice in respect of another specific company. Costigan also reveals that in early 1976 another opinion was obtained about a scheme involving Norfolk Island, and that opinion by a senior member of the Sydney Bar again advised that the scheme could be attacked by a criminal prosecution for conspiracy. One possible reason that this constant and firm advice was not followed could be that the Attorney-General's Department was snowed under prosecuting other cases. If this was the case, and the Costigan report's comments on the operation of that Department make me somewhat sceptical, then the Department should examine ways in which prosecutions can be farmed out to private legal practitioners. That proposition has been seriously put to me by many people in the community who believe that the Attorney-General's Department in this case has been quite negligent.

It seems to me that in the Government's action to crack down on tax avoidance over the past seven years much credit is due to the Australian Taxation Office which has quickly identified schemes, brought them to the attention of the Government and drafted legislation to deal with them. Unfortunately, I believe that the Tax Office has been let down by the Crown Solicitor's Office which has demonstrated a lamentable reluctance to prosecute tax avoidance cases. The failure by this Office does not, however, warrant the present legislation which will have the effect of involving many innocent people in prosecutions.

The dangers of retrospectivity are clear. It is not conducive to proper justice to make illegal today the actions of yesterday. If this approach were adopted it could lead to many abuses upon the Australian community. As a member of the Liberal Party, I believe in and attempt to reflect the principles of that party. In our newly released platform our opposition to retrospective legislation is clearly made known. Our platform states:

The rights of the taxpayer are safeguarded by minimising discretionary powers; assuring taxpayers of a fair hearing before judicial and administrative bodies; maintaining confidentiality of information; ensuring that taxation adjustments do not have retrospective effect.

This very wise provision in the Liberal Party platform has been given consideration and reconsideration over a great number of years by a lot of people in the community involved with the Liberal Party who for very severe and serious reasons believe that this provision should remain. They expect us, as Liberal members of parliament, to defend that principle and not to abandon it. I believe that they have acted with a very real purpose in mind, recognising that subsequent irresponsible governments could come to power and impose retrospective taxes in many areas. It could well be that Mr Hayden's threat to bring in a capital gains tax could be dealt with in a retrospective fashion. It could well be that company taxes could be increased and made retrospective. Those are the things that I would be concerned about, those are the things that the Liberal Party of Australia is concerned about, and that is the reason why this principle is written firmly and enshrined in the platform of the Liberal Party of Australia. This present legislation, in seeking to recoup tax deemed payable as far back as 1972, will obviously have a retrospective effect. If the party that I represent in this place wants me to support retrospectivity it should strike that section out of our platform.

Recently in New South Wales the Wran Government suggested that it would amend its Stamp Duties Act to deal with payment of stamp duties on documents relating to New South Wales that were prepared outside that State. This would have meant that the legislation would have operated retrospectively to as far back as 62 years ago. Quite properly and quite rightly the New South Wales Liberal Opposition opposed that measure strongly, objecting to these changes on the basis of Liberal Party principles opposing retrospectivity. That amendment was subsequently withdrawn, very wisely, by the Wran Government. That case and the legislation currently before us bear striking similarities. They both seek to collect taxes avoided through legal loopholes and in both cases it is argued that existing legislation could be used to recapture taxes lost to revenue. The main difference, however, is that while in New South Wales the Liberal Party opposes such a measure on the grounds of opposition to retrospectivity, here in Canberra the Government of the same party is supporting retrospective legislation. The New South Wales action exemplifies my concern about retrospectivity. I believe that the Australian Labor Party would not hesitate to use that type of legislation.

Recently in a speech to the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Law Council of Australia, Senator Evans, the Opposition's legal spokesman, clearly indicated that retrospective measures would be used by a future ALP government. Following his speech on 2 November the Australian newspaper editorial stated:

The message was clear-a future Labor Government would have no qualms about adopting the retrospective precedent now established by the Fraser Government and using it in every conceivable case to squeeze the tax lemon dry . . . Senator Evans's proposed legislative war on tax avoidance sounds positively vindictive.

Senator Evans's attitude is in marked contrast to that of his former eminent colleague, former Senator John Wheeldon. In 1977, during the debate on the Curran legislation, Senator Wheeldon, as recorded on page 2571 of Hansard for 8 June 1978, stated:

I think it would be appropriate if I were to intervene just briefly at this time to reaffirm the opposition of the Australian Labor Party to retrospective legislation. However odious one may feel the practices are that one is legislating against, it is our view that retrospectivity is a very evil principle and one which is undermining the principles of the rule of law.
Obviously the ALP no longer has qualms about enacting retrospective legislation. I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on two occasions stating my view quite plainly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope he answered it.
—Yes, he did. He is courteous enough to acknowledge his colleagues even though they occasionally disagree with him. On 30 September this year I wrote to the Prime Minister as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I write regarding the taxation legislation which was introduced into Parliament last week.
You are aware of my attitude to the principle of retrospectivity as I have expressed my opposition to this course of legislative action both with Party forums and publicly in the past.

There is only one circumstance which would persuade me to agree to applying retrospectivity to taxation legislation and that is if the Treasurer publicly details schemes which are regarded as illegal, and foreshadows legislative action that will be taken to collect taxes that are avoided between the announcement and the passage of legislation through Parliament.

I would suggest that on such occasions, the Treasurer should clearly detail the schemes, publicly declare them to be illegal, foreshadow legislation to deal with them and, in addition, notify all societies of accountants, lawyers and tax consultants of the Government's intentions.

This would not only clear up many of the problems that Party members have with retrospectivity, but would also warn the public that the schemes were illegal. If the schemes persisted, it would be obvious that the lawyers, accountants and tax consultants were flagrantly breaking the law and should be dealt with together with those of their clients who evaded tax in this way.
I wrote to the Prime Minister on 4 October in these terms:
My dear Prime Minister,

Following the introduction of the package of taxation bills into Parliament, I have consulted with a prominent constitutional lawyer and others, who have raised a number of points that, I believe, need to be examined before the bills proceed.

1. CONSTITUTIONALITY: It has been suggested that whilst retrospectivity is not illegal under Australia's constitution, the current package may be challenged in the light of past Australian legal precedents. It is argued that Kidman's case and others may not be sufficient precedent to cover all aspects of the legislation.
