If doubts do arise, then costly and protracted legal challenges may ensue. This would obviously render law changes ineffective and would delay the recoupment of taxes criminally defrauded under ''bottom of the harbour'' schemes.
2. HUMAN RIGHTS: It is also argued that the changes may be in contravention of article 15 section 1 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights -

'No one shall be held guilty of any criminal offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute a criminal offence, under National or International law, at the time when it was committed'.
Given that Australia has only recently ratified this covenant, it would seem to ignore one of its tenets.

3. HIGH COURT PRECEDENTS: The High Court has, in the past, provided lawyers, accountants and tax specialists with guidance in taxation matters. The Court, while not condoning tax evasion, has stated that one has a right to minimise tax payments. It has been suggested that the proposed legislation might run counter to the tenor of these decisions.

The Court has also served notice (Mason. J., Cridland 1977) that section 260 of Income Tax Act needed strengthening. It has been argued that in any legal challenge on this package of bills, this may be taken into consideration.

In my view, these matters require detailed examination. In the meantime I believe the Government should begin prosecutions using existing legislation and avenues available under the Income Tax Act, Companies Act and section 86 (e) of the Crimes Act.
The Prime Minister acknowledged receipt of that letter. He told me that he had referred those comments and copies of my letters to the Treasurer.

I believe many people are worried that the legislation which we have before us could possibly have some holes in it. I believe that it was hurriedly prepared. As a result, I think that many innocent people could be caught in the net that we are spreading at this time. I do not believe that this legislation has been properly drafted. I think that has been indicated in the Press. The Australian Financial Review of 25 October 1982 states:
The Taxation Department is concerned that the rush with which the retrospective tax legislation was prepared has left it full of technical faults.
'There could be some quite significant technical problems still in there,' a departmental official said yesterday. 'We are not pretending otherwise.'
Further on, the article states:
Since it is a 61-page, highly technical document drafted in weeks rather than the months which officials would usually demand for accuracy's sake, the potential for error is high.
I was interested also to read comments made publicly by the Law Society of Australia as reported in the Australian of 15 October this year. I shall quote some of it:

Opposition to the Federal Government's planned retrospective tax legislation mounted last night when the Law Society of Australia claimed it contained ' dangerous anomalies' which would seriously interfere with the legal rights of Australians.
Don Mackay, the President of the Council of the Society, is reported in the article as saying:

We are particularly concerned that innocent people will be tangled up and become victims of hurried legislation . . . it appears the rights of innocent shareholders will not be protected because of political expediency.
The article continues:

Although the council has expressed strong support for the Government's campaign against tax evasion, Mr Mackay said it believed the proposed retrospective measures were 'contrary to fundamental rights and freedoms'.
Further, I noted more recently, on Friday 12 November, that a headline in the Australian stated 'Retro tax row alarms Wall St'. I shall quote some of the article:

The bitter controversy over retrospective tax legislation has damaged Australia 's image as a sound financial haven among many members of the US investment community. And grave doubts about the precedents created by such a move have been expressed in London . . .
In the US, Mr Nicholas Bratt, manager of the Scudder group's big Wall Street international fund told the Australian: 'It's one more nail in Australia's coffin as far as we're concerned.'
In judging the investment climate in overseas countries, US money managers are particularly nervous of anything that smacks of a retrospective application of laws.
Any such legislation is seen as setting dangerous precedents for unpredictable 'banana republic' action against investors, including wholesale nationalisation.
Further on Mr Bratt says something with which I totally agree. He says:
We don't like the look of your Labor party.

I say 'hear, hear' to that. I believe that what we are contemplating in this legislation is travelling down a road that is dangerous and unacceptable to the Liberal Party of Australia. I support anything to deal with these scurrilous parasites in our community who have fraudulently evaded tax, but let us deal with them firmly and positively. Let us strengthen section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, as we have been advised to do-although we have ignored the advice. Let us deal with the matter under existing legislation. I shall support any amendment to this legislation which will give protection to those innocent people to whom I have referred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Liberal senator from South Australia, I support the package of Bills before the Senate. I note that I am about the fifteenth or twentieth speaker in this debate, which has ranged over about three days, and that many views have been expressed conscientiously by senators from all parties. It is unlikely that I shall say anything new. However , I want briefly to put my own views on the legislation and emphasise the reasons why I believe the Senate should pass the Bills. All of us have been able to express our views clearly in this very well conducted debate in the Senate. My colleague from South Australia, Senator Jessop, is representative of those among my colleagues in the Liberal Party who are opposed to the legislation. None of us would deny them their right to express their point of view on these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: No one has yet spoken in this debate who is in favour of fraudulent evasion of tax. All of us are protesting about the cheating of the public purse that has been fully brought to light in reports, expecially those before the Government this year. It becomes then a question of judgment as to whether the measures that are before the Parliament will be the best path to follow to overcome this evasion and to determine what is the balance of principles-political and legal- that ought to gain priority in our minds when we come to making a decision on the Bills.

Let me briefly reconstruct the initial public concern that was very loudly expressed throughout Australia when the impact of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the interim report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union about fraudulent tax evasion came to light. At that time, expecially in August and September of this year, the public expressed the view overwhelmingly that this cheating of the public purse had to be stopped and that the money that had been evaded should be recovered. So we have before us these Bills drafted by the Government, all of which are called unpaid company tax assessment Bills. It is in order to recover this money that the Government is responding to the rage expressed publicly throughout Australia at that time. Even though some weeks have gone by now, let us not forget the public's rage about so much money not being lawfully paid into government revenue.

The two reports that I mentioned have brought to light the fact that some $600m has been evaded through a scheme which has been widely discussed as the bottom- of-the-harbour tax evasion scheme. Ten thousand individual Australians were involved in this scheme over a period of about 10 years; that is, they were vendor shareholders in some 4,000 companies that were disposed of in the way that is now quite widely known as the bottom-of-the-harbour method. Forty promoters were involved in advancing arguments to these 4,000 companies that they could manage their affairs in this way and gain financially. Over this period $600m that was in fact already a debt to the branches of the Australian Taxation Office in the various States has just not been paid-company tax has not been collected-because the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme followed a process whereby there was nobody to answer for the debt that was on the books of the Australian Taxation Office.

The great majority of Australians pay tax as they earn their income-by the week , by the fortnight or by the month-and they have no possible access to any such scheme that would evade the contribution that they make proportionally to the tax revenue that provides for government services throughout Australia. When 5 million or more ordinary taxpayers see a small minority making a gain of $600m through these fraudulent schemes it is quite understandable that they will express views to their representatives in this Parliament, whether in the House of Representatives or in the Senate, about taking steps to make sure that these schemes are stopped and that the money which is unpaid finally goes into government revenue. I believe that these fraudulent evasions are corrosive of our society. They undermine the sense of fairness in the taxation system; they undermine the fairness of laws as they operate between all Australians and they ruin public confidence in the taxation system itself.

Some speakers who are opposed to this legislation have referred to the principle of retrospectivity. All of those who have supported the Bills, and I join them, have referred to this principle as one which may be transgressed only rarely. But of all the principles that are before us I believe that we must put into perspective the principles of fairness and confidence in the public's mind in the tax system. The balance of principles we must ensure by passing these Bills that the public does have confidence in the tax system and does see that there is a law which is operating fairly as between all Australians.

This month the Bulletin published a public opinion poll that had been conducted by the Morgan Gallup Poll Australia-wide in October. It asked some 1,844 men and women what their opinions were about this package of Bills. Two-thirds of the people involved in that representative poll supported the new law. They supported these Bills that would recover the money that had been evaded through these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Sixty-five per cent of all people involved in the poll supported the new laws. Only 16 per cent were opposed and 19 per cent were undecided. As is set out in the article in the Bulletin published on 16 November this year, it was clear to all of those who were asked the poll questions that this was unusual law and that it would act in a retrospective way . Nevertheless, two-thirds of them expressed support for the retrospective Bills that are now before us. I believe that that was a credible poll. The result is consistent with the estimate I have made after talking with people, particularly in South Australia. I seek leave for the results of that poll, as published in the Bulletin, to be incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those who are opposed to the Bills have said that they have possible constitutional problems or that they were hastily drafted and ought to be delayed a little so that they can be refined to overcome any possible ambiguities. I do not ask for delay and I do not believe that we should entertain those arguments here. The public of Australia expects the Parliament to order the taxation affairs of the country so that fraudulent evasion will not go on and moneys that should be paid to the Australian Taxation Office are, in fact, collected.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major aspects of this debate has been the contribution from those who have put forward a so-called innocence clause. They acknowledge that there has been fraudulent evasion of tax but say that perhaps some of the 10,000 people in question have been involved in these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes unwittingly or innocently. Moreover, it is said that they may suffer some hardship in the payment of this tax that is now to be recouped from them as vendor-shareholders in the original companies. I do not believe that these Bills have anything to do with guilt or innocence. No one is guilty; no one is innocent. The Bills seek to recoup moneys. The Bills are about recoupment, not guilt or innocence. Let each individual make his own assessment about morals, values or involvements in the law. It is a question of recouping moneys that, it has never been doubted, have been owed to government revenue. I do not see any need for an innocence clause. What is being required is that the money that various vendor- shareholders and promoters have gained at the expense of the Australian Taxation Office be now paid. That is the case with all money that the Taxation Office, after a financial year, may recoup from a taxpayer because a liability has emerged.

A person who, through a miscalculation of tax liability, has been required to pay a further amount of tax is not adjudged innocent or guilty. He is subject to recoupment of moneys that are owed to the Taxation Office. I believe that that is the case in this instance. So, by passing these Bills, we would not be subjecting those required to pay the uncollected taxes to some moral sanction of the Senate or of the Parliament-that they are thereby guilty of some immoral offence. Let that judgment be made by individuals on their heads. But we are asserting that moneys that ought to be paid to the tax revenue should be collected.

There have been arguments against these Bills that have centred directly on the principle of retrospectivity. It has been argued that the Bills will set a precedent. That is nonsense. Retrospective laws have been passed by every parliament in Australia and by similar parliaments overseas. On every hand there are precedents for retrospectivity. It is a matter for judgment in each individual circumstance as to whether the high principle of not allowing retrospective law should be transgressed in order to maintain some more important principle, the principles in this case being the exercise of fairness and retention of the confidence of the public in the taxation system.

In this debate we have seen some lawyers and accountants who are almost unable professionally to contemplate any law that is retrospective. I respect their consciences on this matter. I respect their values and their professional training but I have also observed that less purist lawyers and accountants who have participated in the debate in the Senate, or earlier in the House of Representatives, have I believe spoken more directly as politicians. They have not tossed aside their consciences to support these Bills. Yet they have gone through the same law schools and read the same authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you give us a table of relative purity?

—I use the word 'purity' in the academic sense. Some of those opposed to these Bills have said quoting all sorts of eminent lawyers, all sorts of learned academic opinion, that to go down the path of retrospectivity would be to undermine the rule of law in society, or to take away certainty in the law . Great play has been made of these principles. None of us will take lightly the experience and careful arguments of learned people. But I do not believe that the views of those whose tender consciences on this matter, because of their legal or accounting training, have led them to be reluctant concerning it, have impressed the great majority of those in the Senate or in the House of Representatives. What is clear is that there is certainly no criminal element of retrospectivity in the Bills before the chamber. It still remains my view to oppose totally any retrospective creation of criminal law. No penalty is involved in this law nor is a retroactive crime created.

SPEECH.PARA: A pre-existing tax liability is to be collected now, through the procedures that are set out in the Bills, from the vendor shareholders and the promoters who made a financial gain as a result of processes in which their companies were involved. It is, in fact, not with very much surprise that we hear reference to the purist principle by some lawyers and accountants in the Parliament. Perhaps, because of their training, lawyers and accountants are conscientiously incapable of contemplating anything that would transgress retrospectivity. Let that be their tender consciences and their view which they have well expressed in the Parliament. The majority of us, I believe, in our own way are conscientiously responding to the clearly expressed rage of the public that such a corruption of the tax system can continue and that we are left powerless, because of such a principle, to effect a remedy. I believe that first of all, we are in this Parliament as politicians and as representatives of the people. We should make sure that where there is a gross transgression in the fairness of law or in public confidence in it we take the steps to remedy that situation.

Reference has been made to the Liberal Party's platform. I, as a Liberal, take very seriously the statements set out in the platform and, indeed, the policies on which our Government goes to an election. To my knowledge-this was alleged by Senator Chipp earlier in the debate-the Government of which I am a supporter did not rule out by any explicit statement at the last election or any preceding election the possibility of these Bills being introduced. Similarly, the Liberal Party in its platform has expressed a number of principles and important guidelines. Ultimately, in a debate like this we have the duty to weigh conscientiously the principles and to come to a conclusion. I notice that only a few honourable senators have referred to promoters and to the clauses of these Bills that relate to the promoters of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Those honourable senators who have referred to those parts of the Bills that relate to promoters have applauded the inclusion of recovery action against those people who have been mostly responsible for perpetrating these tax evasion schemes. I join with them. I believe that not only should we gain fairness and justice in this matter by legislating against those who have taken on the whole taxation system in this way but also we should serve notice on those would-be promoters in the future who might dream up and promote some other fraudulent evasion scheme which is against the clear intentions of the law.

I welcome the fact that the vendor-shareholders will not have to pay any penalty in relation to the amount of money that is to be recovered. I believe that in an earlier draft of the Bill that was a possibility. I believe that because of the retrospective aspect of this legislation there should not be any penalty. I certainly welcome the form in which the legislation is now presented. It should be noted that the tax debt that accrued in 1973, 1974, 1975, 1976, 1977 or whatever the year in which it accrued is the amount that is to be recovered in 1982 or possibly 1983. The real value of the money that was not collected during the 1970s has decreased to some extent because of inflation. The tax that is required to be paid by these Bills is in real terms a lesser amount than the money which was then a debt to the tax revenue. To that extent, with the profitability that has come to those in whose hands the money rested in those years because of their ability to invest the money and to make a gain from investment, it is still undeniably the fact that these persons from whom the money is to be collected have, in fact, had the opportunity of further gain from that money. I do not want to see a penalty placed upon them because of the retrospective aspect of this legislation.

In conclusion, I come back to the remarks that I made at the very beginning of my speech-at the time when this matter was most before the public there was an overwhelming expression of rage that the tax revenue could be cheated through these devices. There was a call for the representatives of the people in this Parliament to bring about a remedy. I believe we have that remedy in the same way as in the 20 or 30 instances of legislation which have been brought in by this Government to overcome tax evasion over recent years. I support the Bills strongly. In doing so I do not in any way give away in all circumstances the principle of retrospectivity. It remains an important principle that should be transgressed only rarely and where there is a flagrant introduction of unfairness, as we see in these instances. I note that the Opposition is supporting these Bills, perhaps two-thirds of Government members are supporting the Bills and, I am not sure maybe half the Australian Democrats are supporting the Bills. So, it would appear that these Bills will pass the Senate this week and that we will see demonstrated to the public of Australia a remedy that is sufficient to deal with the problem of tax evasion that has developed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this taxation legislation as other members of the Opposition support it despite the fact that it is limited. Before I start on this subject I must make the point, however, that we have just been listening to a speech by Senator Teague which, I believe, was more difficult to work out than today's crossword. I think some senators may have had the same problem with respect to it as I had.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills before the chamber constitute the Government's response to an industry which ripped off hundreds of millions of dollars from public revenue. The response is a belated one and it is an inadequate one. It is a response which is seven years too late. It is a response which does not do half what its proponents claim it does. As I said, the Opposition supports the Bills. It does so on the basis that in government it will extend the ambit of the Bills. The legislation does not do anything to bring to account those people associated with the Liberal Party of Australia, those wealthy supporters who are currently running the campaign against the legislation; nor does it go far enough.

The Government is trying to have it two ways in respect of this legislation. If it is tackling action which was legal at an earlier time why now does it distinguish this action from other forms of tax avoidance which have been highlighted in the series of reports by the same royal commissioners? If the action was then illegal why has the Government done nothing for the last five years in respect of it? As I said, the tax avoidance industry is essentially a recent one. Let me look at some quotations to support my claim. In the third interim report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union the Royal Commissioner says:

This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years , at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush.
He goes on to say:
The impact on the community has been very serious.

We have had report after report in the last five or six years from the Commissioner of Taxation highlighting the problem. Between the 1975-76 financial year and the 1980-81 financial year we have had an increase of over 2,500 per cent in the numbers of persons identified as tax avoidance participants. The Government's response to this explosion has been quite limited. In fact, report after report of the Taxation Commissioner highlights the problem. I refer to page 11 of the current report. The Taxation Commissioner said:

There has been a substantial abatement in the use of tax avoidance schemes in 1981-82, but the number of experienced staff required to be allocated to the on- going task of detecting, monitoring, investigating and contesting tax avoidance schemes continues to make serious inroads into resources available for other administrative functions.
On page 22 of the report the Taxation Commissioner, in respect of investigations , said:

The continuing decline in the extent of investigation activity to detect tax evasion, as illustrated in the following comparative statistics, is a direct result of the need during the year to deploy substantial resources (estimated to be in the region of 143 man-years) to the investigation of tax avoidance schemes and to other areas of administration. As I noted last year, undetected evaded tax which would have been detected had resources not been required for investigating avoidance activities is a substantial additional cost of tax avoidance.

Therefore, we have had the Taxation Commissioner, year after year over the last six years, highlighting the problem. In a recent series of articles in the Australian Financial Review, David Solomon, a legal commentator, said:
Tax avoidance as an industry is a comparatively recent phenomenon.
In fact, he goes on to highlight the start of the problem and refers to the Barwick decision in the case of the dry Slutzkin scheme. Chief Justice Barwick- in those days-said:

. . . the choice of the form of transaction by which a taxpayer obtains a benefit of his assets is a matter for him; he is quite entitled to choose that form of transaction which will not be subject to tax, or subject him only to less tax than some other form of transaction might do.

Essentially what Chief Justice Barwick said then was, 'I am opening the gate. Whoever likes to hop into this tax evasion scheme can very well do so and the High Court in interpreting legislation in a very strictly literal sense will step out of your way.' The problem is a major one. It has only been in recent months that Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association calculated that almost $7,000m was lost in tax avoidance and tax evasion schemes in the last financial year. It is no wonder that Professor Mathews, a consultant to this Fraser Government, in 1980 said:
. . . personal income tax is a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner.

One of the problems that has caused this major scandal in Australian economic history has been our company law. Federal government after Federal government either has not been allowed to tackle or has not tackled the problem of company law. I can do no better than quote Mr Ralph Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, who in a debate in the House of Representatives in respect of the same legislation said that the Costigan report had found that:
Blue collar thuggary is married to white collar crime by seemingly respectable celebrants.

That is precisely what has happened. In Australia we can set up companies with $ 2 and thereafter get involved in all sorts of lurks. Compare this situation with the situation throughout the world. Compare the situation with that in Great Britain where companies have to put up something like #50,000. The absence of a significant minimum share capital ensures that we have shell companies and facilitates a system of tax avoidance. That has been highlighted not only by the Taxation Commissioner and the McCabe-Lafranchi report but also by the New South Wales Government Corporate Affairs Commission, which estimated that approximately 4,000 companies in that State could be involved in tax avoidance schemes.

One group of people in this community pays for the problem that has been highlighted by the reports. It is not the rich friends of the Liberal Party, it is not foreign companies; it is those in the community who can least afford to pay. It is those wage and salary earners who have increased tax taken out of their pockets because of what has been happening in the corporate sector. It is those other middle income families who, because of decreased revenue to government, find themselves either paying more taxation or deprived of those services which they should be entitled to receive. In looking at the taxation figures we can see that wage and salary earners in fact are subsidising the tax parasites.

In the 20 years from 1961-62 to 1981-82, there has been an increase of 38 per cent in the proportion of tax paid by pay-as-you-earn income earners. In that same period, there has been a decrease from 20 per cent to 13 per cent in the total tax paid by companies. In the last five years, those on salaries have paid over 148 per cent more of the tax cake and their wages have gone up by only 98 per cent, whereas the corporate sector, to which I referred earlier as blossoming under this Government, has had an increase of 73 per cent in its share of the tax cake while its income increased by 125 per cent. Those figures starkly show who is now paying much more tax. Those figures relate not to more of a tax cake of the same size. In fact under the Fraser Government, the Government that promised to alleviate the tax burden, the tax burden has increased. The proportion of gross domestic product paid by wage and salary earners-25.5 per cent-is the highest ever in this country's history and compares with the figure of 23.1 per cent when this Government took office.
I quoted Professor Russell Mathews earlier. I will quote him again. In respect of this point, he said:
The taxation system has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes and wealth in favour of the rich.

Government speaker after Government speaker in this debate has said that the Government has done all it can, has acted nobly and has acted in all haste. With respect, the facts, the record, do not show this. The Costigan Royal Commission does not show this. Other associated reports also give the lie to the Government 's claim. The Government has failed to commit itself to effective means in this legislation. It has failed to do so in the past. It has failed to launch prosecutions under legislation which was passed in 1980. It took the combined efforts of the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports to shame it into some kind of activity.

In the Costigan report, there was detailed very clearly the spectacle of department fobbing off responsibility to department for over seven years. It is true that the first prosecution was authorised in the middle of 1975 under the Whitlam Labor Government. That file managed to find its way to the bottom of a drawer of an office in Perth. But that was not the only time when the problem was highlighted and presented to government. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) by his own admission knew in February 1978 that there was a major problem. The Commissioner of Taxation told him so in correspondence which has been presented to this Parliament. In May 1978, the Commissioner of Taxation made that clear when he 'recommended that a new criminal offence be created to catch those involved in current year profit strips'. In a report to the Treasurer in 1979, a statement which appears also in correspondence which has been tabled in the Parliament and which was dragged out of the Government by the Senate, the Commissioner of Taxation said:
The problem of straw companies and straw trust evasion is already very serious and growing. It is my considered advice that the situation needs to be remedied urgently and with stern measures.

The evidence shows that the Commissioner of Taxation did not leave it there. In fact the evidence also shows that for 18 months corres- pondence floated between the Treasury, the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department. Then we got the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. As I said earlier, it still took at least two years and the full impact of McCabe- Lafranchi before the Government was stormed into taking some action.

Let us look at the action encompassed by this legislation. Let us look at what the Government is doing compared with what it claims it is doing. What is proposed in this legislation is once again a network of loopholes, a sieve, for tax avoidance. If we analyse the Bills we find that we are presented with essentially a 12-point program for continued tax avoidance. It is a program that would do former Attorney-General Sir Garfield Barwick proud. Let us look at the dry Slutzkin scheme. It is one that has been discussed in this Parliament time and time again. The Government repeatedly has not distinguished between a dry Slutzkin scheme and a wet one. In May 1981, in discussing amending legislation to part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Treasurer said:

The effect of this further legislation is that the persons who stand to profit most by company stripping activities, the vendor shareholders also stand to pay heavily for any involvement in such activities.
He went on to say:
The proposition applies to both bottom-of-the-harbour strips and strips of tax company profits.
Mr Costigan, in his fourth interim report, volume 1, reported at pages 72 and 73 :

The assets and liabilities of the target company were then transferred to the new corporate entity, leaving, at the end of the day, a target company with only cash in the bank. The amount of cash in the bank was equal to the accumulated profits, plus the current year profits (if any). The cash in the bank reflected that equation, and it was on that amount that the percentage constituting the promoter's commission was calculated. The total amount of cash in the bank was the money that was then used to finance the purchase of the shares.

Costigan makes no distinction. The Treasurer, in his lead-up to this legislation , made no distinction but when the legislation was introduced we saw a distinction. A dry Slutzkin-type case is excluded and the cost to revenue of this one decision is calculated as being as much as $600m. It is quite ironical that this is somewhere near the amount of money that the Government is now crying out for to spend on job creation schemes. That money could much more easily come to it if it were to act effectively against tax avoidance. But it seems that its priority is very much to leave that money in the hands of those who, year after year, have avoided taxation and not put it in the hands of wage and salary earners in this community. This indicates the Government's priorities -priorities which, I believe, are objectionable not only to the Labor Opposition in this country but also to the overwhelming number of the electorate.

Let us analyse the legislation further. We have a new clause 3 (12) in this Bill which does not sit too easily with the legislation which was withdrawn. We could call it the Horgan provision, the description given to it by my colleague Senator Walsh. Under this provision we find that a quarter of the companies which the Government initially intended to cover will not be covered by this recoupment legislation. Effectively, a company, after being stripped of its assets, which entered a post-sale tax avoidance scheme to reduce or eliminate tax is now exempt. So we will now have vendor shareholders escaping scot-free even though they received inflated prices for their shares. This third sieve is that the Bill is complex and is suited to the Peter Kleins of this business world. The fourth point is that clause 3 (2) of the legislation excludes as directors those persons acting in the performance of the functions attaching to their professional capacity or, as the Bill states, 'to his business relationship with the directors'. This clause exempts the professional masterminds of this scheme.

I turn now to clause 3 (11). It was rather intriguing that Senator Teague saw some virtue in the Government not imposing a penalty tax but I have had constituent after constituent coming into my office-some of them are on incomes as low as invalid pensions-telling me that they have to pay taxation because, for some reason unknown to themselves, they did not include something in their tax returns-a mistake honestly made at the time. They have not been given the indulgence of 12 months in which to pay their unpaid tax. In fact those people are penalised from the moment the taxation was not paid. This legislation goes out of its way to do that; in fact the Government is bending over backwards to accommodate tax avoiders. They are given 12 months in which to pay but there is no penalty tax even though the original Bill provided for a 30 per cent penalty. Interim legislation provided for a 20 per cent penalty and now we find that these tax avoiders are exempt from a penalty. So money which has been in the pockets of these people for four, five, six or seven years, and will probably be so for the next couple of years-as Senator Teague pointed out, it is now deflated in value-will not incur a penalty.

Let me go on to the sixth sieve. It is a problem which has been highlighted in respect of one particular case already. I believe it will be a continuing problem for law enforcement officers in this country. Clause 4 (8) provides that notices need to be served on the individuals involved. In the future we could have a situation in which a tax crook skips the country and skips liability even though he still has assets in Australia. The seventh part of the tax sieve is clause 5 (1) (j), which imposes a rather unusual test. This test provides that if business is carried on after the last sale the company is exempt.

It would not take too much ingenuity on the part of tax evaders, with their word processors and all sorts of associated instruments, to concoct a business after the last sale. These artificial schemes are very much the cause of the problem. Under this legislation these artificial schemes could very well continue. The eighth part of the sieve, I believe, stems from clause 5 (1) (m). This clause will effectively mean a tax deduction for the fees paid to the tax promoters. In fact, the taxpayer will be subsidising fees paid by vendor shareholders to tax promoters during the course of their ripping off of public revenue.

I turn to the ninth part of this sieve which has been presented to us by the Government. I believe it is the combined effect of clause 5 (1) (g) and clause 5 (2) (g). It presents a loophole in a situation in which a company is stripped at the same time as or just before the company entered into a tax avoidance scheme. The vendor-shareholder could argue that at the time the company was sold it did not have a tax liability, a liability for unpaid taxation, and, as a consequence , the company is exempt. It would not take too much for an artificial scheme to organise for a company to sit within that special provision.

I refer now to the tenth point in this respect. Tax avoiders will now be given time to pay when millions, if not billions, of dollars are involved, whereas the poor individual taxpayer in this community has been screwed down year after year by penalty fines and the strict enforcement of legislation, even in circumstances where individuals have been living on invalid pensions. The eleventh point relates to the fact that there will be no attempt to recoup tax which was lost and which would otherwise have been paid on dividends distributed to shareholders. This is a rather scandalous situation. It does not sound as though it will be a big cost to revenue, but the Treasurer, in correspondence to the shadow Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis, dated 8 November 1982, said:

Had such amounts, totalling some $1280m in profits, been distributed as dividends in the years in which the companies were stripped, it is thought that about $500m in income tax would have been payable.

The Treasurer went on to make a rather well documented case for the introduction of a capital gains tax, a case which I tend to agree with. Despite that, in the vicinity of $500m will be lost to revenue because of the distinctive decision of this Government. Let me make one point in respect of this correspondence. There is nothing new in the figures. None of the figures would have been hard for the Treasurer to find. But the Treasurer waited until two days after the debate took place in the House of Representatives before he had enough gall to present the shadow Treasurer with that information.

The last point of this legislation which I find objectionable relates to the naming of persons involved in tax avoidance schemes. Those persons who have been involved in understating their taxable income are detailed in the annual reports of the Commissioner of Taxation. There is nothing new about that. We have a major financial scandal which has embarrassed the Government. We now find that the Government, in order to protect those people with whom it is extremely closely associated-documentation has been produced by the Opposition in respect of this matter time and time again-and who have been involved in this billion dollar tax rip-off, is saying that those people will not be named by the Taxation Commissioner. The naming provision was included in the initial legislation. It no longer sits in this legislation. That highlights the approach of this Government. The Government wants to be seen to be doing something but it does not want to be seen to be doing what it is precisely doing.

We have had argument after argument by Government senators and Government spokespeople about the retrospective nature of the legislation. They say they find something objectionable with it. They say that it does not agree with Liberal Party philosophy. They say that it is unfair, uncertain and so on. Let us initially have a look at Liberal Party philosophy. I refer to the Communist Party Dissolution Bill 1950-a rather scandalous piece of legislaion for a number of reasons. In that legislation, no other person, no greater a person-and I imagine there would not be a greater one in Liberal Party history-than Prime Minister Menzies introduced legislation retrospective and criminal in nature and imparting all sorts of horrific penalties. In 1950 the then Mr Menzies is reported as saying at page 2006 of Hansard:

Not one of us in this House has any love for retrospective legislation. But quite clearly, as a matter of plain horse sense, if this bill dealt only with those who could be shown to be Communist party members on the date on which this bill becomes an act obviously there would then be no party members or officers to be affected by it and the legislation would be a complete futility. We are not prepared to facilitate a farce of that kind.

Sir Robert Menzies, the founder of the Liberal Party, in 1950 saw a need and a role for retrospective legislation. But let us not leave the matter there. Let us look at what was said by Mr Hunt, the Liberal Party leader in the upper House of the Victorian Parliament. An article in the Melbourne Age of Monday 22 November 1982 stated:
The Leader of the Liberal Party in the Upper House, Mr Hunt, said that in 21 years in Parliament he had supported more than 150 pieces of retrospective legislation with a clear conscience.
'If anyone tells me that is not Liberal, or contrary to principle, I say we don 't belong to the same party,' he said. 'It's nonsense to create an overall principle where none exists.'
The article continues:

'There is no such principle that all retrospective legislation is contrary to the principles of the party. What has happened this time is that someone who didn't like bottom-of-the-harbour legislation has sought to raise a principle and use it to criticise the Government by innuendo.'

TALK.START.PARA: —False raising of principles.

—False raising of principles. One can ask why this push has started within the forums of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. The answer is very clear. We will find that the people in the Liberal Party in Western Australia are those who are most directly implicated by this scandalous affair. However, it is interesting to note the views of members of the Liberal Party through the ages on retrospectivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Australian legal system have also made some comments in respect of retrospective legislation. I will quote one of them. Mr Justice Adam in the case D'oro v. Victorian Railways Commissioner in 1960-and this is a principle with which I agree-said:

The strength of the presumption against retrospectivity in any particular case, and accordingly the ease or difficulty with which it may be overcome, must, I would think, depend on the nature and degree of the injustice which would result from giving the statute a retrospective operation.
He went on to say:

On the other hand, where to give retrospective operation to a statute might be considered to work some injustice to one party, but is clearly required to rectify a manifest injustice to others, there would, on principle, seem little reason for giving much weight to the presumption.

That is precisely the situation we have now when hundreds of millions of dollars are being ripped off from the public purse. This money has to be made up by other sectors of the community and in that sense retrospectivity is justified.

The argument has been put in respect of so-called innocent vendor-shareholders. This has been the catchcry of those most deeply implicated in this matter. They say that the innocent vendor-shareholder is the one who will have to foot the bill. It is rather curious that in the last three months-three months of intensive debate-not one innocent vendor-shareholder has come forward and said; 'I am going to be unfairly penalised by this government legislation'. In fact, as my collegue Senator Robert Ray said earlier today, it is harder to find one innocent vendor-shareholder in this country than it was to find one Nazi after World War II. Let us look at the case put forward by the dissidents in the Liberal Party. Let us assess it on the basis of the long stated Liberal principle of 'grab the money and run', and let us reject it. I believe that the legislation is inadequate. But because of the extent to which it does go, the Labor Opposition and I will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are debating the group of Bills under the general heading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bills, otherwise known as the Government's recoupment legislation or, probably wrongly, as the Government's retrospective tax legislation. I will not go through how the bottom -of-the-harbour scheme worked; that has been gone through in great detail by previous speakers, but I wish to make a couple of points. First of all, the necessity for this legislation was brought about by the said scheme. We are dealing with people who received a benefit because funds that should have been set aside for the payment of a company's tax were not so set aside. In other words, the vendor shareholders about whom we are talking received, when they sold their company, a sum which was considerably greater than they could reasonably have expected in a normal commercial sale-because the promoters to whom they sold their company had no intention of paying that company's tax liabilities. I think it is important that most people should understand right from the start the fact that money for that purpose was not set aside, that the companies concerned had tax liabilities and the promoters who bought them had no intention of paying that tax. I imagine that that is the crux of the whole problem. That is why we are where we are today.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall deal now with this legislation so far as retrospectivity is concerned. In very basic terms, retrospective revenue legislation attempts to create new income tax liabilities. This legislation plainly does not do that, so it can hardly be retrospective in the full sense of the term. In this case the stripped company's income tax liabilities are still outstanding to the Commonwealth. They were due when the company was stripped and they are still due. The recoupment tax legislation seeks to make the vendor-shareholders and promoters personally liable for the stripped company's income tax liability. To that extent the vendor-shareholders and promoters will now be personally liable and the legislation can be said to be retrospective in nature. I dare say that that is the problem with the misunderstanding concerning the meaning of the word ' retrospective'. There is, shall we say, an element of retrospectivity in the legislation but it is certainly not retrospective legislation in the full sense of the term. I think everybody who is paying any attention to this legislation should understand one thing right from the beginning: The law was broken when untaxed company profits were stripped. We have not made a new law that says that what was legal in the past will now be illegal. The law was broken when the company, which had an unpaid tax liability, was stripped. It is not correct to infer that somehow or other we are now making illegal what was then legal.

This recoupment legislation serves one purpose and one purpose only: It short circuits the massive legal problems connected with the multiple prosecutions and simply recovers unpaid taxes which are owed, and have been all along, to the Commissioner of Taxation. It does not make anything illegal, it does not make anything a crime, it does not create a new offence and it does not make people criminals. All that it requires is that those who benefited from the evasion of tax, which was always legally payable, now pay what is owing. I think it must be said that it also provides rights of objection against the recoupment of unpaid tax-the same rights as any citizen has when seeking reassessment.

I turn to the innocence clause. This has been brought up quite often and quite genuinely by many people who are concerned that people might have got involved in these schemes without knowing their full intent. Unfortunately, I think it is a basic tenet of law that ignorance is no excuse under the law. I suppose we can all recall at some stage or another being pulled up by a traffic policeman and saying that we thought we were in a 100-kilometre zone when in fact, we were not . That does not wash. We have to have a better story than that. Ignorance is no excuse under the law. Even if somebody in the car had told a driver that he was in a 100-kilometre zone and the driver told the policeman that, he would still not be likely to get out of the fine if he were in an 80-kilometre zone. There is a fair onus on the driver and a responsibility on the taxpayer.

The proponents of the innocence clause overlook-in some cases, I think, deliberately, in others quite concernedly-the fact that this recoupment legislation is only a revenue law. The legislation does not connote any guilt or innocence. It is not a criminal law. Thus, any talk of an innocence clause is irrelevant to the purpose of the recoupment legislation. One either owes the Commissioner of Taxation money or one does not. One can seek a reassessment and if it is favourable one is better off. For legislation to contain an innocence clause it has either to connote guilt or innocence. I think it is worthy to recognise that approximately six million people pay direct tax in Australia today. About 5,000 or 6,000 companies and about 12,500 vendor-shareholders are involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. As I have said on many occasions, Australia is a large land mass with a very small tax base, vis a vis many other countries. Thus, we quite rightly expect our Government to provide good transport, communications, defence, education and health. It behoves every taxpayer to accept his or her responsibility and pay his or her share of tax. Unfortunately, in society today many people see it as their business to get out of accepting their responsibility.

Tax dodging seems to be indicative of a malaise that exists in the land today. When I spoke in the debate on the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, I said that meat substitution was indicative of the greed and selfishness that exists in society. Dodging of taxes is really no different from the meat substitution scandal. The Government has given notice also that it will stop dealings in the cash economy. That is indicative also of the greed in society. People are dodging tax in this way, probably to a greater extent than those involved in the wet Slutzkin scheme. Quite rightly, the Government provides members of the business community with means to minimise their tax. Let us face it, the business community is the engine room of our society. It keeps the economy going and provides jobs. I have no objection to tax minimisation. Most people would welcome the fact that there is provision for businessmen to minimise taxes in order to put more money back into their businesses. But a few go beyond the measures provided and seek to rip off the whole system. In ripping off the system they rip off this country and the rest of the people who accept their responsibility.

Senator Chipp and a few other people have mentioned morality. Of course, we cannot legislate for morality but we must question morality at a time when we are seeking to have a wage freeze in this country. I am not debating that. There are plenty of good, cogent arguments for that, but one must question the morality of people in this chamber who advocate a wage freeze for the wage earners of this country and who, at the same time, would let people get away with dodging their responsibility and their obligations to the whole of society through the tax system as it exists in Australia.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 14 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government planning a massive advertising campaign to popularise some of the alleged vote-catching items in the 1982-83 Budget; if so, who directed that the advertising campaign be carried out and what will be the cost of the campaign to the Australian taxpayer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: Several departments are jointly conducting an integrated advertising campaign in the second half of November drawing the attention of members of the public to their entitlements under a number of Budget measures, most of which became effective from 1 November.

The campaign consists of a general TV advertisement briefly highlighting the main measures which came into effect in November-personal tax reductions, home loan interest tax rebates, changes to social security entitlements-as well as increased assistance to youth through student schemes and work experience programs.
The aim of the television advertisement is to alert as many people as possible to their entitlements.

To support the TV campaign there are separate press advertisements which will give details of social security benefits, housing aid and assistance to youth. Each of these advertisements advises the public on how to take further action to obtain their entitlements. Information material in pamphlet form is also being prepared to follow up the Press advertising on housing by assisting people who deal with the public on housing matters to be better able to advise their clients.
Total expenditure on advertising for the integrated campaign will be about $2m. Funds will be provided by the participating departments.

The Government was aware that the public would need further information on the Budget measures which came into effect on 1 November so that they could, as appropriate to their circumstances, make applications for the various entitlements.

I might add that this campaign is consistent with the recommendation of the Task Force on Departmental Information that 'due consideration be given to the effectiveness of other than print media in communicating with disadvantaged groups, for example radio and television . . .'.

The need for the program is recognised by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate who claimed people are not being told adequately about Government welfare programs (Senate Notice on Motion No. 28), and by the Opposition Spokesman on Social Welfare, Senator Grimes, who said 'what is needed is a proper advertising campaign' including the use of television. (John Singleton program 25 October).

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October (Hansard, page 1686) Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question was concerned with the processing of part of the wool stockpile of the Australian Wool Corporation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

A limited authority has been given to the Australian Wool Corporation to arrange for the processing of wool it acquires in the operation of the reserve price scheme. Wool purchased at auction by the Corporation under the reserve price scheme is stored both in Australia and at overseas locations adjacent to major wool processing areas. The processing authority provided to the Corporation enables it to decide where such processing may more appropriately be carried out.

The Corporation has in stock significant quantities of wool which normally would be carbonised. The recent authority given to the Corporation facilitates the carbonising of these wools in Australia and substantial orders have been placed with seven local wool processing firms in recent weeks to process such wool. In a period when these firms are experiencing very depressed orders and turnover, the Corporation arrangements are helping to keep the industry's specialised work force in employment.

It is not practical to give an assurance that 'such authority will be withdrawn once the stockpile of carbonised wool has reached a satisfactory level'. Given the sluggish demand for wool and the continuing purchases by the Corporation under the reserve price scheme of wools suitable for carbonising, it is difficult to know to what extent the stockpile of carbonised wools may rise.

It should be noted, however, that the Corporation is required by the Wool Industry Act 1972 to perform its functions for the advantage of Australian woolgrowers and the Australian economy, and it is certainly not envisaged that the Australian Wool Corporation would make decisions in breach of that obligation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2112) Senator Button asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the Bureau of the World Heritage Committee has requested the Australian Government to provide: 'A statement of intent regarding the construction of dams, on the possibility of extending the protected area of South West Tasmania and establishing a co-ordinated mechanism to manage this site'? Has the Bureau requested this statement of intent from the Australian Government? What arrangements have been made to provide a reply to the information requested by the Bureau and who in fact has the responsibility to forward Australia's response on this matter? Will the answers be provided before the World Heritage Committee meets, I think in December or early February?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Bureau of the World Heritage Committee met in June this year to consider the nomination by the Australian Government for the World Heritage List of the Western Tasmanian Wilderness National Parks. The Bureau agreed to recommend to the full Committee at its session in December 1982 that the nomination be accepted for listing but agreed to ask the Australian authorities to provide a Statement of Intent regarding construction of dams and other works in the nominated area including relevant details of the area to be flooded. The Bureau has also suggested that consideration be given to adding some other areas to those already nominated.

At present the question of Commonwealth action in relation to South West Tasmania is under active consideration by the Government. When the matter has been determined, an appropriate response will be made by the Government to the World Heritage Committee.
